[Exam: Part II 2018] Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease comprises inherited peripheral neuropathies classified by nerve conduction study (NCS) patterns. Key principles:
• Demyelinating neuropathies (CMT1, CMT3) exhibit markedly slowed conduction velocity (<38 m/s in upper limbs) and prolonged latencies due to myelin sheath loss.
• Axonal neuropathies (CMT2) show reduced compound muscle action potential (CMAP) and sensory nerve action potential (SNAP) amplitudes with normal or mildly reduced conduction velocities and latencies.
• CMTX (X-linked) often produces intermediate conduction slowing (30–45 m/s) and mixed amplitude reduction.
Understanding these electrophysiological distinctions and the underlying gene mutations (PMP22 in CMT1; MFN2 in CMT2) is critical for subtype diagnosis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

CMT2 is defined by primary axonal degeneration. In this case, severely reduced CMAP/SNAP amplitudes with preserved conduction velocity and normal latencies directly correspond to an axonal process, confirming CMT2. The 2019 AAN Practice Guideline on Hereditary Neuropathies endorses NCS amplitude as the key discriminator for axonal versus demyelinating CMT (Level B evidence). Saporta et al. (2011, Neurology) analyzed over 500 genetically confirmed CMT cases and found that MFN2 mutations (CMT2A) present with median CMAP amplitudes <1 mV and velocities >40 m/s. In contrast, CMT1A patients exhibit velocities <25 m/s and relatively preserved amplitudes. Episodic dysarthria/ataxia may reflect transient metabolic stress on already compromised axons, though central features are rare in pure CMT2. Thus, current guidelines and cohort studies uniformly classify this profile as CMT2.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. CMT 1
• Incorrect: A demyelinating subtype with slowed conduction velocity (<38 m/s) and prolonged latencies.
• Misconception: Confusing amplitude reduction in demyelination with axonal loss.
• Differentiator: CMT1 exhibits uniformly slowed velocities, not preserved latencies.

C. CMT 3
• Incorrect: Dejerine–Sottas disease; severe early‐onset demyelination with uniformly very low velocities (<15 m/s) and marked latency prolongation.
• Misconception: Assuming severity equates to axonal pattern.
• Differentiator: CMT3 has extreme slowing and onion‐bulb histology, unlike preserved velocity.

D. CMTX
• Incorrect: X‐linked CMT often shows intermediate conduction slowing (30–45 m/s) plus variable amplitude decrease.
• Misconception: Believing any preserved velocity indicates CMTX.
• Differentiator: CMTX carriers demonstrate mixed features; pure axonal amplitude drop with normal velocity is not typical.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Interpreting low amplitudes as demyelination rather than axonal loss.
2. Over-reliance on latency alone; latencies may remain within normal limits in axonal neuropathies.
3. Misattributing mild velocity slowing in CMTX to demyelination rather than an “intermediate” pattern.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2019 Practice Guideline on Hereditary Neuropathies
– Recommendation: Use CMAP/SNAP amplitude vs conduction velocity to classify CMT subtype (Level B evidence).
2. European Charcot-Marie-Tooth Consortium Consensus Statement, European Journal of Neurology 2020
– Recommendation: Genetic testing guided by electrodiagnostic classification; axonal patterns prioritize MFN2 sequencing (Class II evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

CMT2 pathology primarily affects the axon of peripheral nerves. Axonal degeneration occurs distally in long nerves (e.g., peroneal, sural) where metabolic demands and axoplasmic transport are greatest. Myelin sheaths remain intact, preserving saltatory conduction velocity.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Mutations in MFN2 disrupt mitochondrial fusion and axonal transport. Impaired energy distribution causes distal axonal degeneration, leading to reduced action potential amplitudes on NCS without demyelination.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: distal weakness, sensory loss, foot deformities.
2. Nerve conduction studies: measure CMAP/SNAP amplitudes, conduction velocity, latencies.
3. Classify subtype: axonal vs demyelinating vs intermediate.
4. Genetic testing: targeted gene panels (MFN2 for CMT2; PMP22 for CMT1).
5. Family screening and counseling.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2018 exam. CMT classification by NCS is a frequently tested concept, often in the context of CMAP vs conduction velocity patterns.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder affecting upper and lower motor neurons, leading to muscle weakness and atrophy. Familial ALS (fALS) comprises 5–10% of cases and is most often autosomal dominant. The primary genes implicated are:
• C9ORF72 hexanucleotide repeat expansions (~40% of fALS; often with frontotemporal dementia overlap)
• SOD1 missense mutations (~15–20% of fALS; toxic gain-of-function aggregates)
• TARDBP (TDP-43) mutations (~3–5% of fALS; RNA‐binding protein dysfunction)
• FUS mutations (<5% of fALS; early-onset, bulbar predominance)
Understanding genotype–phenotype correlations guides genetic testing, counseling, prognostication, and emerging targeted therapies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

C9ORF72 hexanucleotide G4C2 repeat expansions were first linked to ALS/FTD in landmark 2011 studies (DeJesus-Hernandez et al.; Renton et al.) and account for ~40% of fALS and ~6% of sporadic ALS (Majounie et al., Neurology 2012). Pathogenic expansions (>30 repeats) form nuclear RNA foci sequestering RNA‐binding proteins and undergo repeat‐associated non‐AUG (RAN) translation into toxic dipeptide repeat proteins, while haploinsufficiency impairs autophagy. SOD1 mutations (~15–20% fALS) produce misfolded protein aggregates causing motor neuron toxicity; TARDBP mutations (<5%) disrupt RNA splicing; FUS mutations (<5%) alter DNA/RNA binding. The 2018 EFNS/EAN guidelines recommend C9ORF72 testing as first-line in all fALS cases for prognostic and therapeutic implications (Level C).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. TDP-43
• TARDBP mutations underlie <5% of fALS.
• Misconception: equating universal TDP-43 inclusions in ALS pathology with high mutation frequency.
• Unlike C9ORF72 expansions, TARDBP mutations involve missense changes in RNA-binding domains.

C. SOD1
• Accounts for ~15–20% of fALS vs. ~40% for C9ORF72.
• SOD1 pathology involves toxic gain‐of‐function protein aggregates, not repeat expansions.
• Often presents with pure motor phenotype without cognitive involvement.

D. FUS
• Causes <5% of fALS and typically presents at younger age with bulbar onset.
• FUS mutations disrupt DNA/RNA processing, far less prevalent than C9ORF72 expansions.

Clinical Pearls

• Offer C9ORF72 testing first in fALS due to highest yield and trial availability.
• C9ORF72 expansions exhibit incomplete penetrance; provide tailored genetic counseling.
• SOD1-targeted antisense oligonucleotide therapy (tofersen) is FDA-approved, underscoring gene-specific treatment.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Mistaking TDP-43 proteinopathy (seen in >90% of all ALS) for high TARDBP mutation frequency.
• Overvaluing SOD1 as the prototype ALS gene, underestimating C9ORF72 prevalence in fALS.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. EFNS/EAN ALS Management Guideline (2018): Recommends first-line C9ORF72 genetic testing in all familial cases (Level C).
2. AAN Practice Guideline on Genetic Testing in ALS/FTD (2021): Advises genetic counseling and testing for C9ORF72, SOD1, TARDBP, FUS in fALS (Level B).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

• C9ORF72 G4C2 repeat expansions (>30) → nuclear RNA foci → sequestration of RNA-binding proteins.
• RAN translation of repeats → dipeptide repeat proteins (poly-GR, -PR, -GA) → neuronal toxicity.
• Haploinsufficiency of C9ORF72 impairs autophagy and nucleocytoplasmic transport.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. Genetic causes of ALS, particularly C9ORF72 repeat expansions, are frequently tested in single-best-answer format, emphasizing mutation frequencies, inheritance patterns, and genotype–phenotype correlations.

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Central Core Disease (CCD) is a prototype congenital myopathy characterized by hypotonia, proximal muscle weakness, and slow progression. On muscle biopsy, cores appear as sharply demarcated, mitochondria-poor zones in type I fibers on oxidative stains (e.g., NADH-TR). Key concepts:
• Sarcomere architecture and excitation–contraction coupling depend on the ryanodine receptor type 1 (RYR1) in the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
• Disruption of calcium homeostasis leads to myofibrillar disorganization and core formation.
• CCD follows an autosomal dominant pattern in most pedigrees, guiding genetic testing and family counseling.

Evidence-Based Analysis

RYR1 encodes the skeletal muscle calcium release channel; pathogenic variants impair channel gating, causing diastolic Ca²⁺ leak, protease activation, mitochondrial depletion, and central core formation. In a cohort of 60 CCD patients, Jungbluth et al. (2016, Neuromuscular Disorders) identified RYR1 mutations in 75% of cases. Otsu et al. (2017, Ann Neurol) demonstrated that murine RYR1 mutant models develop cores identical to human histology. Current consensus (ENMC International Workshop on Congenital Core Myopathies, 2018) designates RYR1 sequencing as first-line genetic evaluation for suspected core disease. Furthermore, RYR1-related CCD confers malignant hyperthermia susceptibility per MHAUS guidelines (2020), mandating anesthesia precautions and dantrolene availability.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Nebulin
• Nebulin (NEB gene) mutations cause nemaline myopathy with rod-shaped Z-disc inclusions, not cores.
• Misconception: both are congenital myopathies but histology (nemaline rods vs. central cores) differentiates them.

C. ACTA1
• ACTA1 encodes α-skeletal actin; variants produce nemaline rods or intranuclear rods on biopsy.
• Key distinction: ACTA1-related myopathies show rods on Gomori trichrome, not loss of oxidative enzyme activity in cores.

D. SEPN1
• SEPN1 mutations underlie rigid spine muscular dystrophy or multiminicore myopathy, featuring multiple small “minicores” rather than a single large central core.
• Confusion arises from “minicore” terminology, but these lesions are multiple and irregular, not centralized.

Clinical Pearls

- Always consider malignant hyperthermia risk in RYR1-mutant CCD; non-triggering anesthetics and dantrolene must be immediately available.
• Core lesions on NADH-TR are pathognomonic; confirm with RYR1 genetic sequencing rather than broader myopathy panels initially.
• Family history of mild childhood hypotonia progressing in adulthood should raise suspicion for dominantly inherited CCD.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating “core” with “rod”: students often misidentify nemaline rods as cores; rods are electron-dense Z-disc derivatives, cores are enzyme-negative zones.
2. Overcalling SEPN1 multiminicores as central cores; minicore lesions are numerous, irregular, and peripherally located, unlike centralized cores.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. European Neuromuscular Centre (ENMC) International Workshop, 2018
Recommendation: Perform RYR1 sequencing as first-line genetic test in all patients with biopsy‐proven central cores. (Consensus grade C, Level IV evidence)
2. Malignant Hyperthermia Association of the United States (MHAUS), 2020
Recommendation: Manage RYR1-mutation carriers as at‐risk for malignant hyperthermia; use non-triggering anesthetics and have dantrolene on hand. (Evidence level B)

Pathophysiology Breakdown

RYR1 mutations alter channel gating, causing chronic sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca²⁺ leak. Elevated cytosolic Ca²⁺ activates calpains and proteases, degrading myofibrils and mitochondria, creating central, oxidative enzyme-deficient cores.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical evaluation: early hypotonia, delayed milestones, family history
2. Laboratory: normal to mildly elevated CK, EMG myopathic pattern
3. Muscle biopsy: oxidative stains (NADH-TR, SDH) to identify central cores
4. Genetic testing: targeted RYR1 sequencing; if negative, consider gene panels for other congenital myopathies

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. It exemplifies the frequent testing of genotype–phenotype correlations in congenital myopathies, particularly the link between RYR1 mutations and central cores on biopsy. Clinically, exam questions often integrate biopsy imagery with genetic associations.

[Exam: Part 2 2024] - Peripheral nerve myelin relies on the PMP22 protein for structural integrity and saltatory conduction.
• Hereditary neuropathy with liability to pressure palsies (HNPP) manifests as episodic focal conduction blocks at common entrapment sites (e.g., ulnar at elbow, peroneal at fibular head).
• Gene dosage of PMP22 is critical: deletion causes HNPP, duplication causes Charcot-Marie-Tooth type 1A (CMT1A).

Evidence-Based Analysis

HNPP results from a heterozygous deletion of the PMP22 gene on chromosome 17p11.2, leading to tomacula (focal myelin thickenings) and susceptibility to pressure-induced demyelination. Multi-center studies (Pareyson et al., Neurology 2001;57:2317) show >80% of HNPP patients harbor this deletion. The 2012 EFNS/PNS guideline recommends using multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification (MLPA) to confirm PMP22 deletion in patients with recurrent focal palsies and electrophysiologic evidence of conduction block. In contrast, PMP22 duplication yields uniform demyelination in CMT1A, and myasthenia gravis features neuromuscular junction transmission failure without focal nerve compression.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. PMP22 duplication
• Causes CMT1A, characterized by symmetric distal weakness and diffuse nerve conduction slowing rather than episodic focal palsies.
• Common error: confusing duplication (CMT1A) with deletion (HNPP).

C. Charcot-Marie-Tooth type 1A
• Presents with uniform demyelination, hypertrophic nerves, pes cavus, and symmetric sensory loss, not isolated compression neuropathies.
• Key distinction: diffuse NCV slowing vs focal conduction block.

D. Myasthenia gravis
• An acquired autoimmune NMJ disorder producing fatigable, often ocular, bulbar, or generalized weakness, without pressure-induced focal neuropathies or conduction blocks.

Clinical Pearls

- HNPP palsies often follow minor compression (e.g., resting elbows on a desk).
• Nerve conduction studies reveal >50% amplitude drop at entrapment sites even between attacks.
• Preventive measures (elbow pads, activity modification) reduce recurrence risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mislabeling all hereditary neuropathies as symmetric; HNPP is episodic and focal.
• Overlooking gene dosage: PMP22 deletion vs duplication have opposite phenotypes.
• Confusing NMJ fatigability in myasthenia gravis with neuropathic conduction block.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. EFNS/PNS Guideline (2012): Recommends MLPA for PMP22 deletion in suspected HNPP (Level A).
2. AANEM Practice Parameter (2020): Supports high-resolution nerve ultrasound to identify tomacula and segmental enlargement in HNPP (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Entrapment occurs where nerves traverse narrow fibro-osseous tunnels—the cubital tunnel (ulnar nerve) and fibular neck (common peroneal nerve)—sites of focal demyelination in HNPP.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Loss of one PMP22 allele reduces compact myelin stability, leading to tomacula (focal myelin thickenings) that predispose to conduction block under mechanical stress.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: recurrent focal palsies after minimal compression.
2. Exam: focal motor/sensory deficits at entrapment sites.
3. NCS/EMG: focal conduction block, segmental NCV slowing.
4. Genetic testing: MLPA for PMP22 deletion.
5. Family counseling and screening.

Neuroimaging Pearls

High-resolution ultrasound reveals segmental nerve enlargement and tomacula in HNPP, distinguishing it from diffuse nerve hypertrophy in CMT1A.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No curative drugs for HNPP; management focuses on mechanical protection, physical therapy, and patient education to prevent nerve injury.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam. Peripheral neuropathies related to PMP22 gene dosage are frequently tested, often contrasting HNPP’s episodic focal palsies versus CMT1A’s symmetric neuropathy.

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis (HypoPP) is a skeletal muscle channelopathy characterized by episodic muscle weakness associated with low serum potassium. Key principles:
• Voltage‐gated ion channels (CaV1.1 and NaV1.4) in the sarcolemma regulate muscle excitability; pathogenic gating‐pore currents underlie attacks.
• Mendelian inheritance patterns dictate recurrence risks; autosomal dominant transmission implies a 50% risk to offspring.
• Differential diagnoses include thyrotoxic periodic paralysis and Andersen‐Tawil syndrome, which have distinct genetic bases and inheritance.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Autosomal dominant inheritance of HypoPP is established by familial segregation studies and identification of heterozygous missense mutations in CACNA1S (1q32) in ~60% and SCN4A (17q23) in ~20% of cases. Jurkat‐Rott et al. (J Physiol. 2000) first described gating‐pore leak currents in CaV1.1 mutants. Subsequent population analyses (Statland et al., Muscle Nerve 2018) confirmed de novo and familial dominantly transmitted mutations. Current UpToDate guidelines recommend genetic testing of CACNA1S and SCN4A in suspected cases, given autosomal dominant transmission (Level C evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Autosomal Recessive
– HypoPP families demonstrate vertical transmission; no reports of disease manifesting only when both alleles are mutated. Common misconception: recessive neuromuscular disorders (e.g., congenital myasthenic syndromes) present similarly.

C. X-linked
– X-linked channelopathies (e.g., Andersen‐Tawil syndrome type 1) involve KCNJ2 mutations and have distinct periodic paralysis plus dysmorphic features. HypoPP lacks X‐linked pedigree patterns and male predominance.

D. Mitochondrial
– Mitochondrial inheritance causes multisystemic syndromes (e.g., MELAS) with lactic acidosis, not isolated hypokalemic paralysis. Misconception arises from energy‐deficit–related weakness.

Clinical Pearls

- Attacks often follow high‐carbohydrate meals or rest after exercise due to insulin‐mediated K⁺ shifts.
• Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (acetazolamide, dichlorphenamide) reduce attack frequency via mild metabolic acidosis.
• ECG during attack shows U waves and flattened T waves corresponding to hypokalemia.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all periodic paralyses with recessive inheritance; only HyperPP can be dominant or recessive depending on gene.
2. Mistaking Andersen‐Tawil syndrome (periodic paralysis + arrhythmias + dysmorphism) for HypoPP due to overlapping weakness.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2022 Practice Advisory on Genetic Channelopathies: recommends first‐line genetic testing for CACNA1S and SCN4A in suspected periodic paralysis (Level C).
• European Neuromuscular Centre (ENMC) 2023 Consensus Statement on Periodic Paralysis: endorses acetazolamide therapy and genetic counseling for autosomal dominant HypoPP (Class II evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Muscle fiber T‐tubule system houses CaV1.1 channels; pathogenic mutations create “gating‐pore” currents that depolarize muscle, impair action potential propagation, and precipitate flaccid weakness.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Missense mutations in S4 voltage‐sensor segments of CaV1.1 or NaV1.4 create aberrant cation leak at resting potentials, promoting sustained depolarization and inactivation of normal channels, culminating in muscle inexcitability.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history of episodic weakness with documented hypokalemia.
2. Exclude secondary causes (thyrotoxicosis, renal tubular disorders).
3. EMG showing reduced CMAP amplitude during attack.
4. Targeted genetic testing (CACNA1S, SCN4A).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Acute: Oral KCl (0.2–0.4 mEq/kg) under ECG monitoring.
• Prophylaxis: Acetazolamide 125–500 mg daily or dichlorphenamide 50–100 mg twice daily; monitor bicarbonate levels and kidney stones risk.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] Myotonia refers to delayed muscle relaxation after voluntary contraction, often due to ion‐channel dysfunction in skeletal muscle membranes. Key distinctions:
• Paramyotonia congenita (PMC) involves paradoxical myotonia—stiffness worsens with continued activity and cold exposure.
• Myotonia congenita (Thomsen or Becker types) shows the “warm-up” phenomenon—stiffness improves with repeated movement.
• Stiff-person syndrome is an autoimmune central disorder (anti-GAD65 antibodies) causing agonist–antagonist co-contraction and rigidity, unrelated to exercise use-dependence.
• Hypokalemic periodic paralysis manifests as episodic weakness (not stiffness), triggered by low serum K⁺, rest after exercise, or carbohydrate loads.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Paramyotonia congenita is a non‐dystrophic myotonia caused by autosomal dominant mutations in SCN4A, the gene encoding the Nav1.4 sodium channel. These mutations impair fast inactivation, leading to sustained depolarization and myotonic discharges that are exacerbated by exercise and cold (Cannon, 2015). EMG classically reveals high-frequency myotonic runs that intensify with repeated stimulation at low temperatures (Griggs et al., 2006). The “paradoxical” worsening sets PMC apart from myotonia congenita, wherein the warm-up phenomenon predominates (Venance et al., 2006). The American Academy of Neurology (AAN) practice recommendations (2021) endorse genetic confirmation for SCN4A mutations in patients with exercise-aggravated myotonia (Level A).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Myotonia congenita
• Incorrect: Warm-up phenomenon; stiffness improves with repeated use.
• Misconception: All hereditary myotonias worsen with exercise.
• Differentiator: Exercise ameliorates rather than aggravates stiffness; cold has less impact.

C. Stiff-person syndrome
• Incorrect: Central GABAergic dysfunction—progressive rigidity and spasms, not true myotonia.
• Misconception: Any muscle stiffness implies channelopathy.
• Differentiator: EMG shows continuous motor unit activity; anti-GAD antibodies positive; no exercise-dependence.

D. Hypokalemic periodic paralysis
• Incorrect: Episodic flaccid weakness, not stiffness; often triggered by carbohydrate load or rest after exercise.
• Misconception: Hypokalemia can cause stiffness.
• Differentiator: Serum K⁺ falls during attacks; EMG shows reduced amplitude, not myotonic discharges.

Clinical Pearls

• Paradoxical myotonia in PMC is best elicited by repeated grip tests in a cold environment—stiffness worsens rather than improves.
• EMG study: cooling the limb accentuates myotonic discharges in PMC but suppresses them in myotonia congenita.
• First‐line symptomatic therapy: mexiletine 200–300 mg TID (AAN Level B).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all hereditary myotonias: students often assume that exercise uniformly alleviates myotonia—fails to recognize PMC’s paradoxical response.
2. Misreading “stiffness” as suggesting stiff‐person syndrome: atraumatic rigidity unassociated with exercise misuse leads to misdiagnosis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Practice Guideline, 2021
– Recommendation: Genetic testing for SCN4A mutations in patients with exercise‐worsened myotonia (Level A).
2. European Neuromuscular Centre (ENMC) Workshop Report, 2022
– Recommendation: Mexiletine as first‐line agent for non‐dystrophic myotonias (Level B); start at 150 mg TID, titrate to 300 mg TID.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

SCN4A mutations in PMC impair the inactivation gate of Nav1.4, causing a persistent sodium current. During repeated muscle activity or cold exposure, the membrane cannot repolarize effectively, precipitating prolonged depolarization and myotonic discharges (Cannon, 2015; Griggs et al., 2006).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: identify exercise-aggravated stiffness and cold sensitivity.
2. EMG: demonstrate myotonic discharges that worsen with repeated low‐frequency stimulation and cooling.
3. Serum K⁺ measurement: exclude periodic paralysis.
4. Genetic testing: confirm SCN4A mutation.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Mexiletine: Class IB antiarrhythmic; blocks persistent sodium current.
– Dosing: start 150 mg TID, titrate up to 300 mg TID as tolerated.
– Monitor ECG for QT shortening, GI side effects.
• Alternative: lamotrigine or acetazolamide in refractory cases.

[Exam: Part II 2019] Autosomal recessive (AR) inheritance in limb-girdle presentations is suggested by consanguineous parents and an affected sibling. Limb-girdle muscular dystrophies (LGMD) are classified by the deficient protein: LGMD2A (calpain-3), 2B (dysferlin), 2C-F (sarcoglycans). Toe walking often reflects early Achilles tendon contractures from muscle fibrosis. In contrast, merosin-deficient congenital muscular dystrophy (LAMA2-related, “lamininopathy”) presents in infancy with hypotonia, delayed milestones and white-matter changes, not adult‐onset toe walking.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Laminin α2 (merosin) is a key basement‐membrane glycoprotein anchoring muscle fibers to extracellular matrix. LAMA2 mutations cause congenital onset (MDC1A) with severe neonatal hypotonia, often respiratory insufficiency and characteristic cerebral white‐matter abnormalities on MRI (Mercuri et al., Neuromuscul Disord 2020). Adult-onset LGMD-like LAMA2 phenotypes (LGMD R23) are exceedingly rare (<5% of cases) and usually present before age 40 with proximal weakness rather than isolated toe walking (Magri et al., J Neurol 2023). By contrast, calpainopathy, dysferlinopathy and sarcoglycanopathies are classic AR LGMDs with onset in childhood or early adulthood, frequently featuring Achilles contractures and resulting toe‐walking gait.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Calpainopathy
– Why it’s plausible: LGMD2A presents in late childhood/early adulthood with scapular winging, lumbar hyperlordosis and early Achilles contractures.
– Misconception: LGMDs never cause contractures – LGMD2A is the exception with prominent early contractures.

B. Dysferlinopathy
– Why it’s plausible: LGMD2B (or Miyoshi myopathy) onset in the late teens/20s with distal calf involvement; chronic fibrosis can lead to secondary contractures and toe‐walking posture in advanced stages.
– Misconception: Late-onset LGMDs cannot produce contractures – membrane repair failure leads to fibrosis over decades.

D. Sarcoglycanopathy
– Why it’s plausible: LGMD2C-F typically begins in childhood/adolescence with proximal weakness, variable calf pseudohypertrophy and progressive fibrosis causing Achilles contractures and toe walking.
– Misconception: Only dystrophinopathies cause pseudohypertrophy – sarcoglycan defects also disrupt the dystrophin–glycoprotein complex.

• Dysferlinopathy often shows the “Miyoshi distal myopathy” pattern: initial calf weakness and atrophy before proximal involvement.
• Merosin-deficient congenital muscular dystrophy presents with floppy infant, delayed motor milestones, elevated CK is mild to moderate and brain MRI shows white-matter hyperintensities.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing congenital muscular dystrophy (e.g., merosin deficiency) with LGMD based solely on protein name (“lamininopathy”).
2. Assuming all AR LGMDs spare distal musculature and do not cause contractures—fibrosis over time leads to joint contractures in many subtypes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ENMC 2022 Consensus on LGMD Classification (Muscle & Nerve 2022): Established clear criteria distinguishing congenital vs limb-girdle phenotypes; recommended standard immunostaining panels including merosin for congenital cases (Level B evidence).
• European Academy of Neurology/Peripheral Nerve Society 2023 Guidelines on Genetic Testing in Neuromuscular Disorders: Advise early use of NGS panels covering CAPN3, DYSF, SGCA-D and LAMA2 in suspected LGMD or congenital MD regardless of onset age (Level A evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Calpain-3 (CAPN3) is a calcium-dependent protease involved in sarcomere remodeling; loss → fiber fragility and fibrosis.
• Dysferlin (DYSF) mediates sarcolemmal repair; deficiency → chronic myofiber necrosis and eventual fibrotic replacement.
• Sarcoglycans stabilize the dystrophin–glycoprotein complex; absence → membrane instability and repeated degeneration.
• Laminin α2 anchors muscle fibers to the extracellular matrix; absence → severe neonatal hypotonia and nonprogressive congenital phenotype.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: age at onset, gait abnormalities, family history of consanguinity.
2. Serum CK: markedly elevated in LGMD2A, 2B, 2C-F; mildly in merosin deficiency.
3. EMG: myopathic changes.
4. Muscle MRI: selective patterns of muscle involvement.
5. Muscle biopsy + immunohistochemistry: screen dystrophin, calpain-3, dysferlin, sarcoglycans, merosin.
6. Confirmatory genetic testing via NGS panel.

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. On board exams, inheritance pattern and age at onset are key to distinguishing congenital muscular dystrophies (e.g., merosin deficiency) from limb-girdle muscular dystrophies. Commonly tested as vignettes contrasting neonatal hypotonia versus adolescent/adult proximal weakness with contractures.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] – Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT)/HMSN is a group of inherited peripheral neuropathies characterized by distal muscle weakness, sensory loss, and slowed nerve conduction.
– CMT1A (∼70–80% of AD HMSN) is caused by a 1.5 Mb duplication of PMP22 on chromosome 17p11.2; CMT1B (5–10%) is due to mutations in MPZ (myelin protein zero).
– Genetic testing follows a stepwise algorithm: first PMP22 duplication/deletion, then sequencing of other common genes (e.g., MPZ, GJB1).

Evidence-Based Analysis

MPZ sequencing is the appropriate next step after ruling out PMP22 duplication because MPZ mutations account for the second most common cause of autosomal dominant CMT1. The American Academy of Neurology (AAN) practice guideline (England et al., 2015) recommends PMP22 copy-number testing first (Level B), followed by gene panel or targeted sequencing—including MPZ—for PMP22-negative cases. A 2023 review in Neurology Genetics reported a diagnostic yield of ∼5–10% for MPZ in AD CMT1 cohorts, with distinct electrophysiological and clinical phenotypes guiding gene selection.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Repeat PMP22 test
– PMP22 copy-number assays (MLPA or microarray) have >99% sensitivity; false negatives are rare. Repeating adds little diagnostic value.
– Misconception: thinking initial assay is unreliable.
B. Test for DGP1
– DGP1 is not a recognized CMT gene; likely confusion with PMP22 or GJB1.
– Misconception: inventing nonexistent genes rather than using established genetic panels.
D. Test for PMP22 deletion
– PMP22 deletion causes HNPP (hereditary neuropathy with liability to pressure palsies), presenting with episodic focal palsies and demyelinating features, not uniform distal weakness.
– Differentiation: HNPP has conduction block at entrapment sites, whereas CMT1 has diffuse slowing.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Hereditary Neuropathy with Liability to Pressure Palsies (HNPP) is a focal demyelinating neuropathy caused by reduced dosage of the peripheral myelin protein 22 (PMP22), leading to susceptibility to conduction block at entrapment sites. Key concepts:
1. Myelin compaction in peripheral nerves relies on correct PMP22 expression; haploinsufficiency causes tomacula (focal myelin thickenings).
2. Gene dosage effects at 17p11.2: deletion of one PMP22 allele → HNPP; duplication → Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease type 1A (CMT1A).
3. Clinical hallmark: recurrent, transient mononeuropathies (e.g., peroneal palsy at the fibular head) often triggered by minor compression.

(Word count: 114)

Evidence-Based Analysis

PMP22, a 22 kDa transmembrane glycoprotein accounting for ~2–5% of peripheral myelin proteins, is encoded on chromosome 17p11.2. In 1993, Chance et al. (Nat Genet 3:38–42) demonstrated that a 1.5 Mb heterozygous deletion at this locus underlies HNPP, confirmed by Southern blot and FISH. This deletion reduces PMP22 transcript levels by ~50%, impairing compact myelin integrity and predisposing to focal demyelination under mechanical stress. In contrast, a reciprocal duplication of PMP22 causes CMT1A, characterized by uniform demyelination and secondary axonal loss. Current American Academy of Neurology (AAN) practice parameters (2019) recommend PMP22 copy number analysis as first-line genetic testing for patients presenting with demyelinating neuropathy with conduction block. Functional studies in transgenic mouse models (Sereda et al., J Neurosci 19:7476–7485, 1999) corroborate that PMP22 haploinsufficiency produces tomacula and conduction slowing. Thus, the correct answer is PMP22 deletion.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. PMP22 duplication
• Incorrect because duplication (three copies) of PMP22 produces CMT1A, not HNPP.
• Misconception: “any PMP22 alteration causes HNPP” (fails to appreciate gene dosage directionality).
• Key differentiator: CMT1A presents with uniform demyelination, progressive distal weakness, and pes cavus, rather than episodic focal palsies.

C. MPZ gene mutation
• MPZ (P0) mutations cause autosomal dominant CMT1B or congenital hypomyelination, not HNPP.
• Represents confusion between major myelin proteins; MPZ encodes structural adhesion protein, not dosage‐sensitive.
• Differentiator: nerve biopsy shows onion-bulb formations in CMT1B, absent in HNPP.

D. GJB1 gene mutation
• GJB1 encodes connexin 32; X-linked CMT (CMTX1) arises from its mutations.
• Misconception: lumping all hereditary neuropathies together; CMTX1 often has CNS white matter lesions on MRI.
• Differentiator: inheritance pattern (X-linked) and male predominance, unlike autosomal dominant HNPP.

Clinical Pearls

1. Nerve conduction blocks in HNPP often normalize between episodes; repeat studies during symptomatic periods increase diagnostic yield.
2. Nerve biopsy is rarely required; when performed, tomacula (“sausage‐shaped” myelin thickenings) are pathognomonic.
3. Advise patients to avoid prolonged pressure (e.g., leg crossing) and wear protective pads to prevent recurrent palsies.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing HNPP with CMT1A due to both involving PMP22: always recall deletion versus duplication.
2. Overlooking focal conduction block in demyelinating neuropathies, leading to misdiagnosis as acquired mononeuropathy multiplex.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Academy of Neurology Practice Parameter update, 2019: recommends PMP22 copy number analysis (deletion/duplication) as first-line genetic test in demyelinating neuropathies with conduction block (Level A).
• Richards S et al., ACMG Standards and Guidelines, 2015: classify PMP22 deletion at 17p11.2 as a pathogenic copy number variant for HNPP based on multiple independent case reports and functional studies (Evidence level 1A).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PMP22 is critical for myelin sheath compactness. Haploinsufficiency leads to defective Schwann cell myelin compaction, promoting focal myelin outfoldings (tomacula). Mechanical stress at sites of nerve compression exacerbates demyelination by triggering Schwann cell–axon detachment and conduction block. Recovery occurs via remyelination but repeated insults may produce secondary axonal loss.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: recurrent, transient mononeuropathies at compression sites.
2. Nerve conduction studies: identify focal conduction block with slowed distal motor and sensory velocities.
3. Genetic testing: targeted PMP22 copy number analysis (MLPA or microarray) to detect 17p11.2 deletion.
4. Counseling: autosomal dominant inheritance; family screening as indicated.

[Exam: Part 2 2024] Metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD) is an autosomal‐recessive sulfatide storage disease caused by arylsulfatase A deficiency, leading to accumulation of cerebroside sulfate in oligodendrocytes (CNS) and Schwann cells (PNS). Core concepts:
• Demyelination vs. axonal injury on NCS: demyelinating neuropathies show slowed conduction velocities (<70% of lower normal limit), prolonged distal latencies, temporal dispersion, and potential conduction block.
• In MLD, peripheral nerve myelin is directly damaged by sulfatide deposition, producing a classic demyelinating pattern on NCS.
• Differentiating demyelinating from axonal neuropathy is critical: velocity and latency abnormalities dominate in demyelination, whereas amplitude reduction is primary in axonal loss.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Metachromatic leukodystrophy’s arylsulfatase A deficiency leads to segmental demyelination of peripheral nerves. Multiple series (Kehrer et al., J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2011) report motor conduction velocities in MLD patients often <20 m/s (normal >50 m/s), with prolonged F-wave latencies and temporal dispersion. The European Leukodystrophy Association Guidelines (van Rappard et al. 2018) recommend baseline and serial NCS for PNS assessment in MLD (Level C evidence). Secondary axonal loss may occur late, but primary findings remain those of a demyelinating neuropathy, distinguishing MLD from purely axonal or mixed neuropathies.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Axonal neuropathy
– Why incorrect: MLD primarily targets myelin via sulfatide accumulation; axonal amplitudes remain relatively preserved early.
– Misconception: all genetic neuropathies are axonal.
– Differentiator: axonal neuropathies show reduced amplitudes with near-normal velocities.

C. Normal nerve conduction studies
– Why incorrect: PNS involvement is universal in MLD, so NCS are abnormal.
– Misconception: leukodystrophies spare peripheral nerves.
– Differentiator: intact NCS are seen only in purely central disorders without PNS involvement.

D. Mixed demyelinating and axonal neuropathy
– Why incorrect: while chronic demyelination can cause secondary axonal loss, early and mid‐stage MLD shows purely demyelinating features without significant amplitude loss.
– Misconception: late‐stage changes define initial pattern.
– Differentiator: mixed patterns have both slowed velocity and severely reduced amplitudes; early MLD amplitudes are relatively preserved.

Clinical Pearls

1. Peripheral NCS in MLD often reveal distal slowing >75% below normal before clinical neuropathy is obvious.
2. MRI “tigroid” appearance in CNS correlates with PNS demyelination on NCS.
3. Early HSCT (before significant NCS changes) can stabilize demyelination and improve long-term outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming a leukodystrophy spares peripheral nerves; MLD uniquely affects both CNS and PNS myelin.
2. Over‐interpreting reduced amplitudes as primary axonal damage; demyelination with conduction block can mimic low amplitudes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• European Leukodystrophy Association Guidelines 2018: Recommend baseline and annual NCS in MLD for disease monitoring (Level C).
• AAN Practice Guideline on Leukodystrophies, 2021: Suggests NCS every 6–12 months to assess PNS progression in MLD (Level B).
• Biffi et al., 2020 (Science Translational Medicine): Gene therapy trial showed improved conduction velocities by 30% at 12 months post-treatment.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Schwann cells in peripheral nerves rely on arylsulfatase A to catabolize sulfatides; in MLD, sulfatide-laden Schwann cells produce segmental demyelination primarily in internodal regions, detectable as slowed conduction on NCS.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Aryl­sulfatase A deficiency causes lysosomal accumulation of cerebroside sulfate, disrupting myelin sheath integrity and leading to concentric “onion‐bulb” Schwann cell proliferation and demyelination.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical: developmental regression, gait ataxia, neuropathic pain
2. MRI brain: periventricular T2 hyperintensities with “tigroid” pattern
3. NCS: demyelinating neuropathy with slowed velocities and prolonged latencies
4. Biochemical: low arylsulfatase A activity in leukocytes, elevated urinary sulfatides
5. Genetic: ARSA gene mutation confirmation

[Exam: Part II 2022] Hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathies (HSAN) are classified by mode of inheritance, age of onset, and fiber types affected.
• HSAN I (SPTLC1 mutation) is autosomal dominant, adult-onset, with axonal degeneration of small fibers (pain/temperature) and often large fibers (vibration), causing distal sensory loss and motor involvement.
• HSAN III (IKBKAP mutation) selectively affects autonomic function and small‐fiber sensation, often sparing vibration.
• HSAN IV (NTRK1/TRKA mutation) presents in infancy with pain insensitivity, anhidrosis, and cognitive issues.
• RET is a proto‐oncogene involved in MEN2 syndromes, not primary neuropathy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

SPTLC1 encodes the long-chain base subunit of serine palmitoyltransferase, which catalyzes the first step in sphingolipid synthesis. Bejaoui et al. (Nat Genet 2001) identified heterozygous SPTLC1 mutations (e.g., Cys133Trp) in autosomal dominant HSAN I families. Mutant SPTLC1 increases production of deoxysphingoid bases, neurotoxic metabolites causing distal axonal loss in both small (C and Aδ fibers) and large (Aβ fibers) fiber populations. Electrophysiology demonstrates reduced sensory and motor amplitudes consistent with axonal neuropathy. The European Academy of Neurology’s 2021 guideline recommends SPTLC1 sequencing in adult‐onset, sensory‐predominant axonal neuropathy with positive family history (level C evidence). Penno et al. (Neurology 2017) performed a randomized trial showing L-serine supplementation lowers deoxysphingolipids and may slow disease progression.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. RET
• Why incorrect: RET mutations cause multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma), not a primary peripheral neuropathy.
• Misconception: Confusing neural crest origin in endocrine tumors with peripheral nerve pathology.
• Differentiator: No sensory or motor axonal neuropathy in RET‐related syndromes.

C. TRKA
• Why incorrect: TRKA (NTRK1) mutations cause HSAN IV (CIPA), an autosomal recessive congenital insensitivity to pain with anhidrosis, present in infancy.
• Misconception: Assuming all pain‐insensitivity disorders have similar electrophysiology.
• Differentiator: CIPA features anhidrosis, early-onset hyperthermia, intact vibration sense, and cognitive deficits.

D. IKAP
• Why incorrect: IKAP (IKBKAP/ELP1) mutations underlie familial dysautonomia (HSAN III), characterized by autonomic crises, GI dysmotility, and variable small‐fiber sensory loss; vibration often preserved.
• Misconception: Equating any autonomic involvement with mixed sensory‐motor axonal neuropathy.
• Differentiator: Prominent autonomic dysfunction (labile blood pressure, alacrima) and Ashkenazi Jewish prevalence.

2. Overlooking large‐fiber involvement in SPTLC1 mutations; HSAN I often includes vibration loss and motor axonal features.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. European Academy of Neurology (EAN) Guideline 2021: Recommends genetic testing (SPTLC1) for adult‐onset, sensory‐predominant axonal neuropathy with family history (Level C).
2. Penno et al., Neurology 2017 (Class II evidence): Demonstrated that L‐serine supplementation in HSAN I reduces deoxysphingolipid levels and slows sensory loss progression.

Pain and temperature are mediated by small unmyelinated C fibers and thinly myelinated Aδ fibers; vibration/proprioception by large myelinated Aβ fibers. SPTLC1 mutation–induced deoxysphingolipids injure all fiber types, explaining combined sensory modalities loss.

[Exam: Part 1 2020] - Familial amyloid polyneuropathy (FAP) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the transthyretin (TTR) gene leading to misfolded protein deposition in peripheral nerves, heart, and autonomic fibers.
• Common early manifestations include bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome (due to amyloid deposition in the flexor retinaculum), length-dependent sensory polyneuropathy, and autonomic dysfunction (orthostatic hypotension, GI dysmotility).
• Cardiomegaly with restrictive physiology often develops as disease progresses, and a positive family history strongly suggests hereditary ATTR amyloidosis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Genetic testing for TTR mutations is the diagnostic gold standard for hereditary ATTR amyloidosis. According to the 2021 International Society of Amyloidosis (ISA) consensus, sequencing of the TTR gene confirms pathogenic variants, enabling presymptomatic family screening and therapy planning (Grade A). Tissue biopsy (e.g., abdominal fat pad) with Congo red staining and mass spectrometry can identify amyloid type but does not replace genotyping. Serum TTR concentration is influenced by hepatic synthesis and nutritional status and cannot distinguish variant from wild-type protein. Early genetic diagnosis is critical in light of disease-modifying therapies: the ATTR-ACT trial (NEJM 2018) demonstrated that tafamidis reduces all-cause mortality and cardiovascular hospitalizations in TTR cardiomyopathy, and the APOLLO trial (NEJM 2018) showed patisiran improves neuropathy scores.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Transthyretin
• Incorrect because measuring serum TTR level does not identify specific TTR gene mutations or confirm amyloid deposition.
• Misconception: Equating protein concentration with genetic variant status.
• Differentiation: Genetic testing confirms genotype; TTR level is nonspecific.

C. Echocardiogram
• Incorrect because, although echocardiography can show restrictive cardiomyopathy and ventricular “sparkling,” it cannot determine the molecular etiology of amyloid.
• Misconception: Belief that imaging alone suffices for definitive diagnosis.
• Differentiation: Echocardiogram assesses organ involvement; genetic testing establishes cause.

D. Nerve conduction studies
• Incorrect because NCS reveal the presence and pattern of neuropathy but do not identify the underlying cause.
• Misconception: Assuming electrophysiological studies can replace genetic confirmation.
• Differentiation: NCS quantify neuropathy severity; genetic testing confirms FAP.

Clinical Pearls

- Bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome often precedes overt neuropathy by years in TTR amyloidosis—consider FAP in unexplained bilateral release surgeries.
• Congo red–positive tissue biopsy confirms amyloid deposition but must be followed by TTR genotyping to distinguish hereditary from wild-type forms.
• Early genetic diagnosis enables timely initiation of tafamidis or RNA-silencing therapies, which have been shown to slow progression and improve survival.

1. Relying on serum TTR levels thinking they identify variant amyloid—fails to distinguish wild-type from mutant protein.
2. Overemphasizing imaging or electrophysiology without pursuing genetic testing, thereby delaying definitive diagnosis and targeted therapy.

- International Society of Amyloidosis (ISA) Joint Consensus Guidelines 2021: Grade A recommendation for TTR gene sequencing in all patients with suspected hereditary ATTR amyloidosis prior to initiating disease-specific treatments.
• European Society of Cardiology (ESC) Guidelines 2022 on Cardiac Amyloidosis: Class I, Level C recommendation for genetic testing in patients with ATTR cardiomyopathy to differentiate mutant from wild-type TTR and guide family screening.

[Exam: Part II 2019] - Peripheral myelin protein 22 (PMP22) is critical for compact myelin in peripheral nerves.
• Hereditary Neuropathy with Liability to Pressure Palsies (HNPP) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a 1.5 Mb deletion on chromosome 17p11.2, including PMP22. Focal demyelination (“tomacula”) at entrapment sites leads to recurrent mononeuropathies after trivial compression.
• Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease type 1A (CMT1A) arises from PMP22 duplication, causing uniform distal symmetric demyelinating polyneuropathy without episodic pressure palsies.
• Myelin protein zero (MPZ) mutations cause CMT1B, a progressive symmetrical neuropathy with variable age of onset, not episodic focal palsies.
• Clinically, HNPP often presents in teens or early adulthood with transient foot or wrist drop following compression.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Deletion of PMP22 underlies HNPP by reducing protein dose by ~50%, impairing myelin stability and promoting tomacula formation at sites of mechanical stress (Li et al., Neurology 2017). In a cohort study (Thomas et al., Brain 2019), 85% of HNPP patients harbored the common 1.5 Mb deletion; the remainder had point mutations or smaller deletions. Nerve conduction studies reveal segmental demyelination with conduction block at entrapment sites (e.g., ulnar groove, fibular head) while preserving proximal conduction velocities. Current consensus (EFNS/PNS 2021 guidelines) recommends first-line genetic testing by multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification (MLPA) for PMP22 copy number in suspected HNPP (Level B evidence). Supportive management—avoiding compression, occupational therapy—remains standard; no disease-modifying pharmacotherapy exists.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. PMZ0
• Not a recognized gene or disease entity. Misrepresents MPZ (myelin protein zero).
• Common misconception: mixing up gene nomenclature.
• Lacks any clinical or genetic correlation to episodic neuropathies.

C. PMP22 duplication
• Causes CMT1A, a chronic, progressive, symmetric demyelinating polyneuropathy with foot deformities and absent tendon reflexes, not episodic mononeuropathies.
• Misconception: gene dosage effects are interchangeable; in fact, deletion and duplication yield opposite phenotypes.
• Uniform conduction slowing on NCS distinguishes it from focal blocks in HNPP.

D. MPZ mutation
• MPZ mutations (CMT1B) present with symmetrical distal weakness and sensory loss, not transient focal palsies triggered by pressure.
• Misconception: all myelin protein gene defects produce similar presentations; clinical onset and distribution differ markedly.
• NCS in CMT1B shows diffuse slowing without focal conduction block.

Clinical Pearls

- HNPP often presents first as a “Saturday night palsy” (radial neuropathy) or foot drop after cross-legged sitting.
• Tomacula (“sausage‐shaped” myelin thickenings) on nerve biopsy are pathognomonic.
• Always include PMP22 copy number testing when encountering unexplained focal mononeuropathies, especially with family history.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating CMT1A (duplication) with HNPP (deletion); the two have opposite gene dosage effects and distinct presentations.
2. Failing to recognize tomacula on biopsy and attributing episodic palsies solely to entrapment neuropathies like carpal tunnel syndrome.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- EFNS/PNS (2021) Joint Guidelines: Recommend MLPA or microarray for PMP22 copy number analysis as first-line genetic test in suspected HNPP (Level B evidence).
• ACMG Technical Standards for CNV Interpretation (2020): Classify PMP22 deletions >1 Mb as pathogenic in HNPP when correlated with clinical phenotype (Expert Consensus).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- PMP22 comprises ~2–5% of peripheral myelin; deletion reduces compact myelin stability.
• Reduced PMP22 leads to focal myelin outfoldings (tomacula), predisposing to conduction block under mechanical stress.
• Repeated demyelination/remyelination cycles can cause mild axonal loss over time.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history of pressure-induced focal palsies.
2. Neurological exam: focal weakness, sensory deficits at common entrapment sites.
3. Nerve conduction studies: segmental conduction block, slowed distal latencies at compression points.
4. Genetic testing: MLPA or microarray for PMP22 deletion.
5. Supportive management: avoid pressure, physical therapy.

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Hypokalemic periodic paralysis (HPP) is an autosomal dominant channelopathy most often due to mutations in CACNA1S (voltage-gated calcium channel) or SCN4A (sodium channel).
• In HPP, episodes of muscle weakness coincide with ↓ serum K⁺ from intracellular shift, frequently precipitated by rest after carbohydrate-rich meals or late sleep.
• Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dichlorphenamide) induce a mild metabolic acidosis, promoting K⁺ efflux from muscle and stabilizing resting membrane potential.
• Distinguish from other causes of paralysis (e.g., myasthenia gravis, hyperkalemic periodic paralysis) by serum K⁺ levels during attack and absence of decrement on repetitive nerve stimulation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Carbonic anhydrase inhibition (Option B) is correct: acetazolamide inhibits renal and systemic carbonic anhydrase, causing bicarbonaturia and a mild metabolic acidosis. The resultant acidemia shifts H⁺ into cells in exchange for K⁺, raising extracellular K⁺ and reducing susceptibility to depolarization-induced Na⁺ channel inactivation in skeletal myocytes.
Randomized, placebo-controlled trials of dichlorphenamide (JAMA Neurol. 2014;71(2):195–204) demonstrated a >50% reduction in attack frequency (Class I evidence). UpToDate reviews and the EFNS guidelines (2012) endorse carbonic anhydrase inhibitors as first-line prophylaxis in HPP (Level B). By contrast, cholinesterase inhibitors (Option A) target neuromuscular transmission in myasthenia gravis, have no role in HPP. “Hypokalemic” (Option C) would worsen attacks by further lowering K⁺. Rest (Option D) is part of precipitating factors, not a therapeutic mechanism.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Cholinesterase
– Mechanism: inhibits acetylcholinesterase to ↑ acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.
– Misconception: conflating HPP with myasthenia gravis.
– Differentiator: HPP has normal neuromuscular transmission; cholinesterase inhibitors exacerbate weakness if K⁺ is low.

C. Hypokalemic
– Mechanism: implies inducing or maintaining hypokalemia.
– Misconception: confusing trigger (low K⁺ causes attacks) with treatment.
– Differentiator: treatment aims to correct or prevent hypokalemia, not induce it.

D. Rest
– Mechanism: physical rest decreases muscle work.
– Misconception: interpreting rest as therapy rather than a precipitant.
– Differentiator: rest often precipitates HPP episodes via post-exercise insulin-mediated K⁺ shift.

Clinical Pearls

• Acetazolamide can unmask sodium channel mutations (SCN4A) by worsening attacks; switch to dichlorphenamide if intolerant.
• Avoid high-carbohydrate late-evening meals and vigorous exercise before bedtime to reduce post-prandial insulin surge.
• Monitor serum bicarbonate and potassium; chronic metabolic acidosis may lead to nephrolithiasis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prescribing potassium-wasting diuretics (e.g., furosemide): worsens hypokalemia and triggers paralysis.
2. Mistaking HPP for myasthenia gravis: repetitive nerve stimulation is normal in HPP but shows decrement in MG.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. European Federation of Neurological Societies (EFNS) Guidelines on Neuromuscular Channelopathies, 2012
– Recommendation: Use acetazolamide or dichlorphenamide as first-line prophylaxis in HPP.
– Level B evidence.
2. FDA Approval Based on Dichlorphenamide RCT (JAMA Neurol. 2014;71(2):195–204)
– Finding: Significant reduction in attack frequency vs placebo (p<0.001).
– Class I evidence; led to orphan drug approval in 2015.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Mutations in CACNA1S or SCN4A create an aberrant “gating pore” current at rest, leading to depolarization of the sarcolemma. During triggers (e.g., insulin release from carbohydrate intake), excessive Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase activity drives K⁺ into cells, hyperpolarizing then depolarizing muscle fibers and impairing action potential propagation, causing flaccid paralysis.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: episodic flaccid weakness, precipitated by high-carb meals or rest.
2. Measure serum K⁺ during attack (usually <3.0 mEq/L).
3. Electrodiagnostic testing: exercise-long exercise test shows amplitude decline in compound muscle action potentials.
4. Genetic testing for CACNA1S/SCN4A mutations to confirm subtype.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Acetazolamide: Start 125 mg BID, titrate to 250 mg TID; monitor bicarbonate, K⁺, and electrolytes weekly initially.
• Dichlorphenamide: 50 mg BID, may reduce attacks with fewer metabolic side effects; monitor for paresthesias and kidney stones.
• Avoid potassium-wasting drugs and high glycemic loads.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Chronic Progressive External Ophthalmoplegia (CPEO) is a mitochondrial myopathy characterized by painless, symmetric ptosis and limited eye movements.
1. Mitochondrial genetics: Large-scale deletions in mtDNA disrupt multiple respiratory chain complexes leading to impaired ATP production.
2. Heteroplasmy: Variable proportions of deleted mtDNA in extraocular muscles drive the late-onset, progressive phenotype.
3. Maternal inheritance vs sporadic events: While some mtDNA point mutations follow maternal transmission, CPEO most often arises from sporadic single large-scale deletions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Large-scale single deletions of mtDNA (commonly 4.9 kb) account for 70–85% of CPEO cases, producing ragged-red fibers on muscle biopsy and COX-negative fibers (DiMauro & Hirano, 2007). This deletion spans genes encoding subunits of complexes I, III, IV, and tRNAs, causing multisystemic energy failure in high-demand tissues like extraocular muscles. Current consensus (Mitochondrial Medicine Society, 2021) recommends targeted long-range PCR to detect these deletions before considering rarer point mutations. Nuclear gene defects (e.g., POLG mutations) can cause multiple mtDNA deletions but present with broader phenotypes (Mancuso et al., 2013).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Sporadic mutation in mitochondrial DNA
• Incorrect: “Sporadic” is vague; CPEO arises from a single large-scale deletion, not random small-scale mutations.
• Misconception: Equating any spontaneous mtDNA change with pathogenic variants.
• Differentiation: Point mutations (e.g., m.3243A>G) cause MELAS or MIDD, not pure CPEO.

C. Mutation in ribosomal-related mitochondrial DNA
• Incorrect: Mutations in 12S/16S rRNA genes cause deafness or aminoglycoside sensitivity (e.g., m.1555A>G), not isolated ophthalmoplegia.
• Misconception: All mtDNA rRNA mutations present with muscle weakness.
• Differentiation: Ribosomal mutations affect protein synthesis globally, leading to multisystem disease.

D. Point mutation in nuclear DNA affecting mitochondrial function
• Incorrect: Nuclear gene point mutations (e.g., POLG1) lead to multiple deletions or depletion syndromes with epilepsy, ataxia, or hepatic failure.
• Misconception: CPEO is always nuclear–encoded.
• Differentiation: Nuclear defects cause secondary mtDNA deletions; primary CPEO is due to a single large mtDNA deletion.

Clinical Pearls

- Always order long-range PCR or Southern blot for suspected CPEO before whole mtDNA sequencing.
• Ragged-red fibers on Gomori trichrome and COX-negative fibers are hallmark biopsy findings.
• Coenzyme Q10 and exercise may modestly improve muscle strength but do not alter disease progression.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming all mitochondrial myopathies follow maternal inheritance – CPEO deletions are usually sporadic.
2. Equating ptosis with myasthenia gravis – CPEO has persistent ptosis without diurnal variation and no acetylcholine receptor antibodies.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Mitochondrial Medicine Society Consensus (MMS 2021): Recommends long-range PCR for single‐deletion mtDNA detection in CPEO (Level C evidence).
2. European Academy of Neurology Guidelines (EAN 2022): Advises coenzyme Q10 supplementation (5–30 mg/kg/day) for symptomatic relief in mitochondrial myopathies (Level B evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

The 4.9 kb mtDNA deletion removes multiple tRNA and complex I/IV subunit genes → defective oxidative phosphorylation → ATP depletion in extraocular muscles → gradual fiber loss and replacement by fat/connective tissue → external ophthalmoplegia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: ptosis + progressive ophthalmoplegia without neuromuscular junction fatigability.
2. Serum lactate/pyruvate ratio (often elevated).
3. Electromyography: myopathic pattern.
4. Muscle biopsy: ragged-red and COX-negative fibers.
5. Genetic testing: long-range PCR → confirm single large-scale mtDNA deletion.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Charcot–Marie–Tooth (CMT) disease comprises hereditary peripheral neuropathies classified by neurophysiology into demyelinating (CMT1) and axonal (CMT2) types.
• CMT1: markedly slowed nerve conduction velocities (NCV < 38 m/s) due to segmental demyelination.
• CMT2: relatively preserved NCV (> 38 m/s) with primary axonal degeneration leading to reduced compound muscle action potentials (CMAP) and sensory nerve action potentials (SNAP).
• Electrophysiology (nerve conduction studies) is key: amplitude drop (axonal loss) vs velocity slowing (demyelination).

Evidence-Based Analysis

The hallmark of CMT2 is axonal degeneration of peripheral nerves, manifesting as reduced SNAP amplitudes on sensory nerve conduction studies. In contrast to CMT1, conduction velocities remain near normal (> 38 m/s) because myelin is intact. England et al. (AAN Practice Parameter, 2019) and the EAN guidelines (2021) affirm that a significant drop in SNAP amplitude with preserved NCV is diagnostic for axonal CMT. Saporta et al. (J Peripher Nerv Syst. 2022) demonstrated that > 90% of genetically confirmed CMT2 patients have SNAP amplitudes < 10 µV, confirming this as a sensitive electrophysiological marker.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Affects upper limbs more than lower limbs
• Incorrect: CMT classically begins distally in the feet (peroneal muscles) before involving hands.
• Misconception: confusing proximal motor neuropathies (e.g., multifocal motor neuropathy) with CMT.
• Differentiator: CMT shows a “stocking–glove” distribution, lower limbs first.

C. Demyelination of peripheral nerves
• Incorrect: demyelination is the primary pathology in CMT1, not CMT2.
• Misconception: equating all CMT with segmental demyelination.
• Differentiator: CMT2 demonstrates axonal loss on biopsy and normal/slightly slowed NCV.

D. Early onset muscle hypertrophy
• Incorrect: CMT causes distal muscle wasting (atrophy), not hypertrophy.
• Misconception: confusing pseudohypertrophy seen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy.
• Differentiator: CMT2 leads to muscle fiber loss and replacement by fat/connective tissue on MRI.

Clinical Pearls

• In hereditary axonal neuropathies (CMT2), SNAP amplitude < 10 µV is nearly pathognomonic.
• Genetic testing panels should follow electrophysiological classification: axonal vs demyelinating guides gene selection.
• Foot deformities (pes cavus) and hammer toes are common early signs in both CMT1 and CMT2.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming all CMT subtypes show slowed conduction velocities—only CMT1.
2. Overlooking the importance of amplitude reduction (axonal loss) in sensory studies for CMT2 diagnosis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. European Academy of Neurology (EAN) guideline on hereditary neuropathies (2021):
– Recommends classifying CMT by median motor NCV threshold of 38 m/s to distinguish CMT1 vs CMT2 (Level A).
2. American Academy of Neurology Practice Parameter: Genetic Testing in CMT (AAN, 2023):
– Advises targeted next-generation sequencing panels guided by electrophysiological subtype (Level B evidence).

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Paramyotonia congenita is a non-dystrophic myotonia marked by paradoxical worsening of stiffness with exercise and cold.
• Voltage-gated sodium channels (Nav1.4, encoded by SCN4A) underlie action potential initiation and repolarization in skeletal muscle.
• Myotonia arises from delayed inactivation of Nav1.4, causing repetitive muscle fiber discharges.
• Different channelopathies present variably: chloride channel (CLCN1) mutations cause classic myotonia congenita with warm-up phenomenon; calcium (CACNA1S) and potassium (KCNJ2) channel mutations underlie periodic paralyses without true myotonia. (120 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Paramyotonia congenita stems from missense mutations in SCN4A that impair fast inactivation of Nav1.4, producing persistent inward sodium current and cold-sensitive myotonia. Functional studies demonstrate that specific SCN4A variants (e.g., T1313M, R1448C) shift inactivation curves and slow recovery, correlating with clinical cold-induced stiffness (Kullmann et al., Brain 2001). Current management guidelines prioritize genetic confirmation (Richards et al., ACMG–AMP 2015) and symptomatic therapy with sodium channel blockers (mexiletine) based on Class I evidence from Statland et al.’s randomized crossover trial (Neurology 2012), which showed significant reduction in stiffness and improved patient-reported outcomes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Chloride channel
• CLCN1 mutations cause myotonia congenita (Thomsen/Becker types) with warm-up phenomenon and improvement with repetitive activity. Cold typically ameliorates stiffness rather than aggravates it.

C. Calcium channel
• CACNA1S mutations underlie hypokalemic periodic paralysis. Patients present with episodic flaccid weakness triggered by carbohydrate load or rest after exercise, without percussion myotonia or cold sensitivity.

D. Potassium channel
• KCNJ2 mutations produce Andersen-Tawil syndrome—periodic paralysis, cardiac arrhythmias, and dysmorphic features. Myotonia is absent and there is no percussion myotonia.

Clinical Pearls

- Percussion myotonia at the thenar eminence is highly specific for non-dystrophic myotonia.
• Cold-induced exacerbation differentiates paramyotonia congenita from other myotonias.
• Mexiletine (200–400 mg TID) is first-line therapy; monitor ECG for QT prolongation.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all myotonias with CLCN1 mutations: chloride channelopathies improve with warm-up, whereas paramyotonia worsens with repeated contraction and cold.
2. Misattributing calcium channel mutations to myotonia: CACNA1S variants cause periodic paralysis without true myotonia on EMG.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Richards S et al., “Standards and Guidelines for the Interpretation of Sequence Variants” (ACMG–AMP, 2015): Recommends rigorous variant classification for SCN4A, incorporating functional, segregation, and population data (Level: Consensus-based guidelines).
• Statland JM et al., “Mexiletine Is Effective and Safe in Myotonia Congenita and Paramyotonia Congenita” (Neurology, 2012): Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover trial demonstrating significant improvement in patient-reported stiffness with mexiletine (Level: Class I evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Mutant Nav1.4 channels exhibit slowed fast inactivation and enhanced resurgent currents. At low temperatures, channel gating kinetics slow further, prolonging depolarization and causing repetitive action potentials manifesting as myotonia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: cold sensitivity, percussion myotonia.
2. Physical exam: confirm myotonia (grip and percussion).
3. EMG: detect myotonic discharges, assess cold-induced changes.
4. Genetic testing: SCN4A sequencing for definitive diagnosis.
5. Initiate therapy (mexiletine), genetic counseling.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Mexiletine: Class IB antiarrhythmic; 200–400 mg orally TID. Titrate to effect; monitor ECG.
• Alternatives: Flecainide and quinine have anecdotal efficacy but less robust data.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. Paramyotonia congenita and SCN4A mutations are frequently tested on neuromuscular boards, often contrasting cold-sensitive myotonia with other channelopathies.

[Exam: Part II 2018] Monomelic amyotrophy (Hirayama disease) is a focal lower motor neuron disorder affecting anterior horn cells at C7–T1. Key principles:
• Lower motor neuron vs demyelinating neuropathy – pure LMN signs (wasting, fasciculations) without sensory loss.
• Dynamic cervical flexion myelopathy – flexion causes posterior dural shift and compressive microcirculatory ischemia of anterior horn cells.
• Differentiation from generalized motor neuron diseases (ALS) by absence of UMN signs, slow progression, and static course after initial worsening.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Monomelic amyotrophy classically presents in adolescent to young adult males with insidious, unilateral distal upper‐limb muscle wasting and weakness, most pronounced in C7–T1 myotomes, with fasciculations but intact sensation and reflexes initially. Dynamic cervical MRI in flexion demonstrates anterior displacement of the posterior dural sac and engorged epidural venous plexus, confirming flexion‐induced cord compression (Tashiro et al., Clin Neurol Neurosurg 2018). Electromyography shows chronic denervation restricted to one limb without conduction block. In contrast, CIDP/AIDP have demyelinating features on nerve conduction studies plus sensory involvement; ALS has combined UMN signs and multisegmental spread (Airlie House El Escorial criteria 2015). No disease‐modifying pharmacotherapy exists; early cervical collar to limit flexion reduces progression (level III evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. CIDP
– CIDP is a chronic, symmetric demyelinating polyneuropathy with sensory deficits, slowed conduction velocities, conduction block, elevated CSF protein without pleocytosis. Misconception: both have weakness and are chronic, but CIDP is demyelinating and sensory.

B. AIDP
– AIDP (Guillain–Barré) presents acutely over days with ascending paralysis, areflexia, albuminocytologic dissociation, and often sensory symptoms. Key difference: acute time course vs insidious onset.

D. ALS
– ALS involves both UMN (spasticity, Babinski) and LMN signs, progressive involvement of multiple regions, possible bulbar symptoms. Monomelic amyotrophy lacks UMN features and remains focal.

Clinical Pearls

• Perform cervical MRI in flexion to visualize posterior dural shift and engorged epidural veins.
• Early cervical collar use can arrest progression by limiting neck flexion.
• Monomelic amyotrophy often stabilizes after 2–5 years, unlike ALS which relentlessly progresses.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking focal distal wasting for carpal tunnel syndrome; always assess for fibrillations and weakness beyond median nerve distribution.
2. Overcalling early wrist extensor weakness as ALS; absence of UMN signs and imaging in flexion are distinguishing.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• European Federation of Neurological Societies/Peripheral Nerve Society (EFNS/PNS) Consensus Statement on CIDP Diagnosis (2010): Defines electrophysiological demyelination criteria (conduction velocity <80% of LLN, conduction block) to distinguish CIDP from other neuropathies (Level A recommendation).
• Airlie House Revised El Escorial Criteria for ALS (2015): Establishes requirement for combined UMN and LMN signs in multiple regions to diagnose ALS; specifically excludes purely focal LMN syndromes like Hirayama disease.
• Tashiro et al., Clin Neurol Neurosurg 2018 (prospective cohort, n=45): Demonstrated flexion MRI changes in 100% of clinically diagnosed patients and showed cervical collar reduced progression in 85% (Level III evidence).

[Exam: Part 2 2023] - Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) refers to inherited sensorimotor polyneuropathies caused by genetic mutations affecting peripheral nerve myelin or axon integrity.
• Subtypes: CMT1A (PMP22 duplication, autosomal dominant demyelinating), CMT2 (various genes, axonal), CMT4 (autosomal recessive demyelinating) and CMTX (GJB1 mutation, X-linked).
• Connexin32 (Cx32), encoded by GJB1, forms gap junctions in Schwann cells and central oligodendrocytes; mutations lead to peripheral neuropathy plus episodic CNS white-matter dysfunction unique to CMTX.

Evidence-Based Analysis

CMTX (X-linked CMT due to GJB1 mutations) is distinguished by both peripheral demyelinating neuropathy and transient central white matter events. Kleopa et al. (Brain, 2002) demonstrated that GJB1 mutations disrupt Cx32 channel function in Schwann cells and oligodendrocytes, causing demyelination peripherally and reversible CNS lesions. EMG/NCS in CMTX shows intermediate conduction slowing (25–45 m/s) compared to CMT1A (>38 m/s) and CMT2 (>45 m/s). The 2020 AAN Practice Guideline on Genetic Testing for Hereditary Neuropathy (Level B evidence) recommends targeted GJB1 analysis when NCS suggests demyelination with CNS signs. MRI often reveals transient bilateral T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in periventricular regions that resolve over weeks.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. CMT2
• Incorrect: Primarily axonal neuropathy (NCV >45 m/s), no CNS involvement.
• Misconception: Equating all CMT subtypes with CNS findings.
• Differentiation: Normal/mildly reduced conductance vs intermediate slowing in CMTX.

C. CMT1A
• Incorrect: AD demyelinating neuropathy due to PMP22 duplication, NCV <38 m/s, no CNS lesions.
• Misconception: Most common CMT subtype implies CNS features.
• Differentiation: Age-matched foot deformities without transient CNS episodes.

D. CMT4
• Incorrect: Autosomal recessive demyelinating neuropathy presenting in childhood; no CNS manifestations.
• Misconception: Severe demyelinating forms have central signs.
• Differentiation: Early onset, ABCD1/GJB1 negative, uniform slowing on NCS.

Clinical Pearls

- Intermediate NCV (25–45 m/s) with episodic encephalopathy suggests CMTX rather than pure CMT1 or CMT2.
• MRI may show reversible T2/FLAIR lesions in periventricular white matter during acute CNS episodes.
• Genetic panels for CMT should include GJB1 when CNS signs accompany peripheral neuropathy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming CMT1A is the culprit in any demyelinating CMT without considering inheritance pattern or CNS features.
2. Overlooking transient CNS symptoms in male patients with X-linked inheritance, attributing them to stroke or MS instead of CMTX.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (2020) Practice Guideline on Genetic Testing for Hereditary Neuropathy: recommends GJB1 testing for demyelinating neuropathy with atypical CNS findings (Level B).
• EFNS/ENS Guidelines (2014) on CMT: advise NCS stratification then targeted genetic analysis, highlighting GJB1 for intermediate slowing and CNS signs (Class II).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Connexin32 gap junctions in Schwann cell Schmidt–Lanterman incisures maintain myelin homeostasis; in oligodendrocytes, they support interlamellar communication—explaining both peripheral and central demyelination.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

GJB1 mutations impair Cx32 channel assembly/function, disrupting ion/metabolite flow between myelin layers → Schwann cell and oligodendrocyte dysfunction → segmental demyelination, axonal loss, transient CNS lesions.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical evaluation: distal weakness, pes cavus, family history.
2. EMG/NCS: determine demyelinating vs axonal vs intermediate slowing.
3. MRI brain if any CNS symptoms.
4. Genetic testing: panel including GJB1 when intermediate NCV and CNS signs.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Reversible confluent T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in periventricular and subcortical white matter during acute episodes; absence of enhancement and resolution on follow-up support CMTX.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No disease-modifying agents; management includes physical therapy, orthotics, neuropathic pain agents. Gene therapy trials in GJB1 knockout models (Ghodsi et al., 2023) show restoration of Cx32 expression.

[Exam: Part II 2022] Charcot‐Marie‐Tooth (CMT) syndromes are hereditary peripheral neuropathies classified by nerve conduction study (NCS) findings into demyelinating (CMT1) versus axonal (CMT2) subtypes.
• In axonal neuropathies (CMT2), pathology centers on degeneration of the axon (particularly distal, length‐dependent fibers), leading to reduced compound muscle action potential (CMAP) and sensory nerve action potential (SNAP) amplitudes.
• Motor nerve conduction velocities (MNCVs) remain within or near the normal range (>38 m/s in upper limbs), distinguishing CMT2 from demyelinating forms (CMT1: MNCVs <38 m/s).
• CMT2A, the most common CMT2 subtype, arises from MFN2 mutations disrupting mitochondrial fusion in long peripheral axons, causing length‐dependent axonal loss with predominant lower‐limb onset.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Upper limb involvement greater than lower limb
• Incorrect because CMT2A is a length‐dependent neuropathy: symptoms begin in distal feet and lower legs before progressing to hands.
• Misconception: assuming a non‐length‐dependent distribution.
• Key differentiator: lower‐limb onset is universal in CMT2A.

B. Loss of SNAPs
• While SNAP amplitudes are reduced in CMT2A, loss of SNAPs also occurs in demyelinating CMT1 after chronic axonal degeneration.
• Misconception: equating amplitude reduction with axonal subtype specificity.
• Key differentiator: amplitude loss is nonspecific; conduction velocity distinguishes axonal vs demyelinating.

D. Predominant demyelination
• CMT2A is an axonal neuropathy; histology shows axonal degeneration without characteristic myelin onion‐bulbs.
• Misconception: conflating all CMT subtypes with demyelination.
• Key differentiator: MNCVs in CMT2A are preserved, unlike in demyelinating forms.
