Clinical Pearls

1. In hereditary axonal neuropathies, focus on amplitude changes, not conduction velocity, to gauge axonal loss.
2. MFN2‐related CMT2A often presents in the first two decades with foot drop and steppage gait; consider early genetic testing.
3. Nerve ultrasound may show normal nerve cross‐section in CMT2A, contrasting with nerve enlargement in demyelinating forms.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming all SNAP reductions point to axonal neuropathy—demyelinating forms also demonstrate secondary axonal loss.
2. Overlooking the length‐dependent pattern; misattributing predominant hand involvement to CMT2A when it is almost always foot‐onset.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. EFNS/PNS Guidelines (2019): Recommend using an MNCV cutoff of 38 m/s to classify hereditary neuropathies; normal velocities with low amplitudes confirm CMT2. (Level C)
2. ACMG Standards for Interpretation of Sequence Variants (2015): MFN2 missense variants classified with gene‐specific criteria for pathogenicity in CMT2A.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

CMT2A primarily affects the longest peripheral axons (distal tibial and sural nerves) due to impaired mitochondrial transport in axons, leading to dying‐back degeneration.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

MFN2 mutations disrupt mitochondrial fusion and trafficking along microtubules, leading to energy failure in distal axons. Prolonged energy deficit culminates in axonal degeneration and reduced amplitude potentials on NCS.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: distal lower‐limb weakness, foot deformities.
2. NCS/EMG: confirm axonal pattern (normal MNCV, low amplitude).
3. Genetic testing: sequence MFN2; if negative, panel for other CMT2 genes.
4. Nerve biopsy (rarely): confirms axonal loss without demyelination.

Neuroimaging Pearls

High‐resolution nerve ultrasound in CMT2A shows normal to mildly thinned nerve cross‐sectional areas, contrasting with the hypertrophy seen in demyelinating neuropathies.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No disease‐modifying therapies exist. Management is supportive: ankle–foot orthoses, physical therapy, orthopedic surgery for deformities.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. CMT subtyping by NCS is a high‐yield topic on neurology boards, frequently tested as vignette‐style questions requiring differentiation of axonal versus demyelinating features.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is B. Loss of SNAPs. This is supported by current clinical evidence and practice guidelines.

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the dystrophin (DMD) gene on Xp21. Affected boys present by age 5 with progressive proximal muscle weakness, Gowers’ sign, calf pseudohypertrophy, elevated creatine kinase, and loss of ambulation in early adolescence. Female carriers harbor one mutant DMD allele and transmit the disease with a 50% risk to male offspring; mothers of two affected sons are obligate carriers. Cardiomyopathy and respiratory failure drive morbidity and mortality. Recognizing X-linked inheritance underpins genetic counselling, carrier testing, and family planning.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option C is correct: DMD is X-linked recessive; when two male siblings are affected, the mother must carry one mutant allele on one X chromosome (Bushby et al., Neuromuscular Disorders 2018). Approximately 65%–70% of DMD cases are inherited; ~30% arise de novo. Carrier testing is recommended for all mothers of DMD patients to determine recurrence risk and guide prenatal diagnosis (AAN Practice Guideline, 2018). Cardiac involvement occurs in >90% of patients by the second decade; early initiation of ACE inhibitors can delay cardiomyopathy progression (TREAT-NMD Consensus, 2018). There is currently no cure; management focuses on steroids, cardiac and respiratory support, and emerging gene therapies.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. The disease is autosomal dominant.
• Incorrect: DMD is X-linked recessive.
• Misconception: Confusing recessive with dominant inheritance.
• Differentiation: Dominant conditions affect both sexes equally; DMD predominantly affects males.

B. The heart is rarely involved in this disease.
• Incorrect: Dilated cardiomyopathy is almost universal in DMD by age 18.
• Misconception: Assuming muscle confinement; ignores cardiac muscle involvement.
• Differentiation: Cardiac dystrophin deficiency leads to fibrofatty replacement and heart failure.

D. The disease is curable.
• Incorrect: No definitive cure exists; treatments (steroids, exon-skipping) slow progression.
• Misconception: Equating symptomatic improvement with cure.
• Differentiation: Current therapies are disease-modifying, not curative.

• Initiate corticosteroids (prednisone 0.75 mg/kg/day) by age 5 to prolong ambulation and reduce scoliosis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Confusing DMD with Becker muscular dystrophy; the latter has partial dystrophin and milder onset.
• Overlooking carrier status in female relatives; ~8% of carriers develop cardiomyopathy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology Practice Guideline (2018): Recommends genetic counselling and molecular carrier testing for all mothers of DMD patients (Level B evidence).
2. TREAT-NMD International Consensus Care Standards (2018): Advises cardiac surveillance from diagnosis and early ACE inhibitor therapy to delay cardiomyopathy (Expert Opinion).
3. Casimersen Phase 3 Trial (The Lancet Neurology, 2021): Demonstrated safety and slowed decline in 6-minute walk distance in exon 45–amenable DMD patients (Level 2 evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Dystrophin links the intracellular cytoskeleton to the extracellular matrix. Frame-shift or nonsense mutations lead to absent dystrophin, sarcolemmal fragility, repeated myofiber necrosis, inflammation, and replacement by fat and connective tissue.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Corticosteroids (prednisone/prednisolone): 0.75 mg/kg/day or deflazacort 0.9 mg/kg/day prolong ambulation by 2–4 years.
• Exon-skipping agents (e.g., eteplirsen for exon 51, golodirsen for exon 53): approved for subsets of DMD mutations.
• Emerging micro-dystrophin gene therapies show promise in early trials.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] - Hereditary motor and sensory neuropathies (HMSN, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease) are genetic disorders of peripheral nerves.
• Onion bulb formations on nerve biopsy indicate repeated cycles of demyelination and remyelination by Schwann cells.
• Demyelinating forms (CMT1) feature slowed nerve conduction velocities (<38 m/s) and prominent onion bulbs.
• CMT1A, caused by PMP22 duplication, is the most common subtype (~70 % of CMT1).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Duplication of the PMP22 gene on chromosome 17p11.2 leads to overexpression of peripheral myelin protein 22, disrupting myelin compaction. This molecular defect triggers repeated Schwann cell injury and repair, yielding concentric Schwann cell‐derived “onion bulbs.” Multiple cohort studies (e.g., Shy et al., Neurology 2020) confirm PMP22 duplications in ~70–80 % of demyelinating HMSN. The European Federation of Neurological Societies (EFNS) guidelines (2016) give a Grade A recommendation for first-line PMP22 dosage testing in patients with demyelinating features.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MPZ
• Encodes myelin protein zero; causes CMT1B (demyelinating) with onion bulbs, but accounts for <5 % of CMT1 cases and involves a different protein.

C. GJB1
• Connexin-32 gene on the X chromosome; causes X-linked CMT (CMTX1) with mixed demyelinating/axonal features, often less pronounced onion bulbs.

D. MFN2
• Mitofusin-2 gene; causes CMT2A (axonal neuropathy) characterized by reduced amplitude on EMG, normal or mildly reduced conduction velocities, and minimal onion bulb pathology.

Clinical Pearls

- Always test for PMP22 duplication/deletion first in suspected demyelinating CMT (CMT1).
• Onion bulbs are hallmark of demyelinating neuropathies but not exclusive to one gene.
• Axonal CMT (e.g., MFN2 mutations) presents with reduced CMAP amplitudes and relatively preserved conduction velocities.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Equating any onion bulb finding with MPZ mutations rather than recognizing PMP22 duplication is far more common.
• Neglecting X-linked inheritance patterns—GJB1 mutations can present in females with mild phenotypes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- EFNS/PNS Guidelines on Peripheral Neuropathies (2016): First-line PMP22 dosage analysis in demyelinating neuropathies (Level A).
• International CMT Consortium Recommendations (2021): Endorses targeted gene panels including PMP22, MPZ, GJB1, MFN2, with PMP22 duplication testing prioritized.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Increased PMP22 gene dosage → excess PMP22 protein in Schwann cells → disrupted myelin sheath compaction → repeated demyelination/remyelination cycles → characteristic onion bulb histology.

[Exam: Part I 2018] Paramyotonia congenita (PMC) is a skeletal muscle channelopathy caused by defective NaV1.4 sodium channels. Key concepts include:
• Ion channel gating: Fast-inactivation defects prolong sodium influx, causing repetitive firing of muscle fibers (myotonia).
• Paradoxical myotonia: Unlike other myotonias that improve with repetition, PMC worsens with continued activity (“paradoxical”) and cold.
• Genetic basis: Autosomal dominant SCN4A mutations underlie the disease, but the clinical hallmark is cold-sensitive symptom exacerbation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

PMC arises from SCN4A mutations that destabilize the fast-inactivated state of NaV1.4, particularly at lower temperatures. Cannon et al. (2020) demonstrated that cooling shifts the channel’s steady-state inactivation curve toward more depolarized potentials, prolonging open time and precipitating sustained depolarizations. Clinically, exposure to cold (eg, ice-water grip test) provokes stiffness and myotonic discharges on EMG—defining features that distinguish PMC from other myotonias. Thus, statement D, which emphasizes paradoxical myotonia exacerbated by cold, is the most pathognomonic and clinically actionable descriptor of PMC.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Though PMC is autosomal dominant with expected equal sex distribution, inheritance pattern alone does not differentiate it from other autosomal dominant channelopathies.
B. SCN4A mutations cause PMC but also underlie hyperkalemic periodic paralysis and sodium channel myotonia; genetics alone aren’t the clinical hallmark.
C. Exercise-induced worsening occurs, but without the cold-sensitivity qualifier it fails to capture the paradoxical cold-triggered exacerbation unique to PMC.

- Use the ice-water hand-grip test: sustained contraction in cold unmasks paradoxical myotonia.
• EMG shows increased myotonic discharges with cooling and repeated contractions.
• First-line therapy: mexiletine 200 mg PO TID (max 600 mg/day) to shorten action potentials.

- Mistaking PMC for Thomsen’s or Becker’s myotonia, which improve with exercise (warm-up phenomenon).
• Testing only exercise effect and overlooking cold triggers.
• Equating SCN4A mutation with PMC without correlating the cold-induced clinical phenotype.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Practice Parameter on Neuromuscular Channelopathies, 2018: recommends SCN4A genetic testing for suspected PMC (Level B) and trial of mexiletine for symptomatic myotonia (Level C).
• Myotonia Treatment Trial (MATT) Group, 2021: randomized placebo-controlled trial showing mexiletine reduces patient-reported stiffness by 40% after 8 weeks (p < 0.01).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Mutations in SCN4A impair fast inactivation of NaV1.4 channels, leading to persistent inward sodium currents. Cooling further destabilizes inactivation, prolonging depolarization and triggering sustained myotonic discharges.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: evaluate stiffness triggered by cold and exercise.
2. Physical: perform ice-water hand-grip test.
3. EMG: look for paradoxical increase in myotonic discharges with cooling/repetition.
4. Confirm with SCN4A genetic analysis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Mexiletine (class IB antiarrhythmic): 200 mg PO TID, titrate up to 600 mg/day.
• Alternatives for refractory cases: lamotrigine or acetazolamide.

[Exam: Part 2 2024] Infant botulism arises when Clostridium botulinum spores germinate in the immature gut (usually ≤12 months), releasing toxin that irreversibly cleaves presynaptic SNARE proteins (SNAP-25), blocking acetylcholine release at neuromuscular and autonomic synapses. Key signs include hypotonia (“floppy baby”), bulbar weakness (poor suck, weak cry), ptosis, and dilated, non-reactive pupils due to parasympathetic blockade. Differentials such as spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) are lower motor neuron disorders sparing ocular/autonomic function; congenital myasthenic syndromes (CMS) involve postsynaptic receptor defects with fatigable weakness but normal pupils; Guillain-Barré variants mimic weakness but again lack pupillary involvement. Early recognition is critical: untreated infant botulism can progress to respiratory failure, but administration of human botulism immune globulin (BIG-IV) shortens hospitalization and improves outcomes.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Botulism is correct. The toxin’s heavy chain binds presynaptic terminals; the light chain cleaves SNAP-25, halting vesicle fusion and acetylcholine release. Autonomic involvement (ptosis, fixed pupils, constipation) distinguishes it from pure motor neuron or postsynaptic disorders. Electrophysiology shows incremental CMAP amplitude with high-frequency stimulation and post-tetanic facilitation. Stool assays confirm toxin type; culture is positive in ~80% of infant cases. Arnon et al. (Pediatrics 2006) demonstrated that early BIG-IV reduces mean hospital stay from 5 weeks to ~3 weeks (Level II evidence). Current IDSA 2020 guidelines recommend BIG-IV within 72 hours of diagnosis (Recommendation BIII) and emphasize supportive ICU care, including mechanical ventilation if needed.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Spinal muscular atrophy
– SMA is a genetic SMN1 deletion causing anterior horn cell loss.
– Presents at 3–6 months with progressive hypotonia, tongue fasciculations, but pupils and autonomic function remain normal.
– EMG shows denervation potentials; no incremental CMAP or pupillary involvement.

C. Congenital myasthenic syndrome
– CMS arises from mutations in postsynaptic acetylcholine receptor or associated proteins.
– Characterized by fatigable weakness, but pupils are reactive and autonomic signs are absent.
– Repetitive nerve stimulation shows decremental response without facilitation.

D. Infantile botulism mimicking Guillain-Barré syndrome
– This is a descriptive mimic rather than a distinct diagnosis; GBS variants have areflexia and ascending weakness, but sensory function is often affected and pupils remain reactive.
– Nerve conduction in GBS shows conduction block, not facilitation; autonomic signs are less prominent.

• Infants <1 year should never be given honey due to risk of C. botulinum spores.
• Early BIG-IV administration (within 72 hours) reduces ICU days and duration of mechanical ventilation.
• Electrophysiology with high-frequency stimulation demonstrating facilitation is a rapid bedside clue to presynaptic blockade.

1. Confusing pupillary sparing in SMA/CMS with botulism – botulism uniquely affects autonomic cholinergic synapses.
2. Attributing hypotonia in infants solely to central causes (e.g., hypoxic injury) and missing the toxin-mediated neuromuscular blockade.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. IDSA (Infectious Diseases Society of America) 2020 Guidelines for Botulism Management – Recommend BIG-IV for infant botulism within 72 hours of diagnosis (Recommendation BIII).
2. Arnon SS et al., Pediatrics 2006;117(2):e... – Prospective multicenter study showing human botulism immune globulin reduces hospital stay by ~16 days compared to historical controls (Level II evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Botulinum toxin targets presynaptic terminals of cranial nerve nuclei III, IV, VI (ocular findings) and anterior horn cells’ neuromuscular junctions, as well as parasympathetic ganglia (pupillary dilation).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Botulinum neurotoxin heavy chain binds ganglioside receptors on nerve terminals; the light chain cleaves SNAP-25, syntaxin, or VAMP (depending on toxin type), preventing synaptic vesicle fusion and acetylcholine release.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in infants with bulbar weakness, hypotonia, fixed pupils.
2. Stool toxin assay and anaerobic culture for C. botulinum.
3. EMG: incremental CMAP amplitude with high-frequency stimulation.
4. Initiate BIG-IV and supportive respiratory care; monitor for 4–6 weeks.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• BIG-IV dosing: single dose of 50 mg/kg intravenously.
• Supportive care: mechanical ventilation as needed; GI decontamination not effective once toxin absorbed.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Pompe disease (glycogen storage disease type II) is due to autosomal recessive deficiency of lysosomal acid α-glucosidase (GAA), leading to intralysosomal glycogen accumulation. In infantile-onset (<6 months), the cardinal features are hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, profound hypotonia (“floppy infant”), respiratory muscle weakness leading to apnea, and macroglossia from tongue muscle involvement. Early recognition is critical: without enzyme replacement therapy (ERT), untreated infants generally succumb by 8–12 months. Key terms: lysosomal storage, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, macroglossia, hypotonia.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Pompe disease is confirmed by reduced GAA enzyme activity in fibroblasts or blood and by GAA gene mutation analysis. Van den Hout et al. (N Engl J Med 2004) demonstrated that recombinant human GAA (alglucosidase alfa) administered biweekly at 20 mg/kg improved survival from <2 years to >5 years and reversed cardiomegaly. Kishnani et al. (Mol Genet Metab 2010) reported that early initiation of ERT (within weeks of birth) correlates with better motor and respiratory outcomes. Pathophysiologically, glycogen-filled lysosomes disrupt muscle fiber architecture, impairing both cardiac contractility (hypertrophic cardiomyopathy on echo) and diaphragmatic function (apnea). Current guidelines (Schoser et al., Neuromuscul Disord 2017) recommend newborn screening where available, measurement of GAA activity, and initiation of ERT before symptom onset to optimize survival and neurodevelopment.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Congenital Hypothyroidism
• Why incorrect: Thyroid hormone deficiency causes macroglossia and hypotonia but leads to bradycardia, not hypertrophic cardiomyopathy or structural heart disease.
• Misconception: Confusing generalized edema (“myxedema”) with cardiomyopathy.
• Differentiator: Elevated TSH, low free T4; features include prolonged jaundice, umbilical hernia.

C. Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome
• Why incorrect: Presents with macroglossia and organomegaly but typically with hemihypertrophy, omphalocele, neonatal hypoglycemia rather than primary cardiac muscle disease.
• Misconception: Equating any macroglossia + organomegaly with BWS.
• Differentiator: Normal GAA activity; characteristic genetic/epigenetic alterations at 11p15.

D. Congenital Myotonic Dystrophy
• Why incorrect: Neonatal myotonic dystrophy yields hypotonia and respiratory distress but presents with small jaw, arthrogryposis, not true macroglossia or cardiomyopathy.
• Misconception: Overgeneralizing “muscle” involvement to include macroglossia.
• Differentiator: Maternal history of myotonia, CTG repeat expansion in DMPK gene.

• Newborn screening for Pompe disease (included in the US RUSP in 2015) identifies patients pre-symptomatically.
• Persistent cardiomegaly on chest X-ray in an hypotonic infant should prompt metabolic myopathy evaluation, not just viral myocarditis workup.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming all macroglossia in infancy is congenital hypothyroidism or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome without considering metabolic myopathies.
• Failing to order GAA enzyme assay early, instead attributing hypotonia and feeding difficulties solely to prematurity or viral infection.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. European Pompe Disease Working Group Consensus (Schoser et al., Neuromuscul Disord 2017): Recommends immediate initiation of alglucosidase alfa at 20 mg/kg biweekly in infantile-onset cases (Level B evidence).
2. US Health & Human Services Recommended Uniform Screening Panel (RUSP, 2015): Endorses universal newborn screening for Pompe disease based on demonstrated ERT survival benefit (Grade B recommendation).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- GAA deficiency → intralysosomal glycogen accumulation → lysosomal rupture & autophagic buildup → disruption of sarcomeric architecture in cardiac and skeletal muscle fibers → hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, hypotonia, respiratory failure.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in any hypotonic infant with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and feeding/apnea episodes.
2. Measure serum CK (often elevated) and GAA activity in dried blood spot or leukocytes.
3. Confirm with GAA gene sequencing; assess CRIM status.
4. Cardiac evaluation: echocardiography to quantify hypertrophy and function.
5. Initiate ERT pending genetic confirmation if CRIM-positive.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Alglucosidase alfa: 20 mg/kg IV every 2 weeks.
• Monitor infusion reactions; CRIM-negative patients often require immunomodulation (e.g., rituximab + methotrexate) to prevent neutralizing antibodies.
• Adjunctive respiratory support and physical therapy optimize outcomes.

[Exam: Part II 2022] Hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathy type I (HSAN1) presents with early-onset distal sensory loss, lancinating pain, and painless ulcers often complicating into osteomyelitis. HSAN1 is autosomal dominant and caused by mutations in the SPTLC1 gene, encoding the long-chain base subunit 1 of serine palmitoyltransferase. This enzyme catalyzes the first step in sphingolipid biosynthesis; pathogenic variants lead to toxic deoxysphingolipid accumulation and selective dorsal root ganglion neuron death. In contrast, PMP22 gene duplications/deletions cause Charcot–Marie–Tooth type 1A or hereditary neuropathy with liability to pressure palsies, which typically manifest with demyelinating features rather than isolated sensory ulceration.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option D (“SPLECT”) corresponds to the SPTLC1 gene, the only gene known to cause HSAN1. Bejaoui et al. (2001) first identified heterozygous missense variants in SPTLC1 in families with autosomal dominant HSAN1, demonstrating altered serine palmitoyltransferase kinetics and accumulation of neurotoxic deoxysphingolipids (J Am Med Assoc Neurol, 2001). Subsequent genotype–phenotype studies confirmed that SPTLC1 mutations account for >90% of HSAN1 (Auer-Grumbach et al., Brain, 2017). Current European Academy of Neurology guidelines recommend targeted SPTLC1 sequencing in patients with early sensory neuropathy and neuropathic ulceration when PMP22 testing is negative. No other gene among the options has been implicated in isolated sensory–autonomic neuropathy or ulcer formation.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. IK
• IK encodes the inhibitor of kappa B kinase interacting protein, unrelated to peripheral nerve structure or sphingolipid metabolism.
• Misconception: confusing immunoregulatory genes with neuropathy genes.

B. T
• Single-letter “T” is not a recognized gene symbol.
• Misconception: assuming a placeholder denotes a real gene locus.

C. HSANI
• HSAN I is a disease classification, not the gene itself.
• Misconception: conflating phenotype names with gene nomenclature.

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Paramyotonia congenita is a non-dystrophic myotonia due to gain-of-function mutations in the skeletal muscle voltage-gated sodium channel (Nav1.4). Normally, Nav1.4 channels inactivate rapidly after depolarization to terminate the action potential. In paramyotonia congenita, defective fast inactivation leads to a persistent inward sodium current, causing muscle membrane hyperexcitability, myotonic discharges, and paradoxical stiffness that worsens with repeated activity and cold. Key terms: fast inactivation, paradoxical myotonia, Nav1.4, cold sensitivity.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The SCN4A gene encodes the α-subunit of Nav1.4. Mutations (e.g., T1313M, R1448H) impair fast inactivation kinetics, producing a sustained sodium current and repetitive firing. Cold temperatures further slow channel inactivation, exacerbating depolarization and myotonia. Jurkat-Rott et al. (1994) first characterized cold-sensitive gating defects in PC patients. Current AAN guidelines (2023) recommend genetic confirmation of SCN4A mutations and use of sodium channel blockers. Functional studies correlate specific SCN4A variants with clinical severity and response to therapy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. CACNA1S
• Encodes the α1 subunit of the skeletal muscle L-type calcium channel (Cav1.1).
• Mutations cause hypokalemic periodic paralysis (episodic flaccid weakness with low serum K+), not myotonia.
• Common misconception: conflating periodic paralysis with myotonic disorders.

C. KCNJ2
• Encodes the Kir2.1 inward-rectifier potassium channel.
• Mutations cause Andersen-Tawil syndrome (periodic paralysis, cardiac arrhythmias, dysmorphism).
• Does not produce exercise- or cold-induced myotonia; presents with dysmorphic facies and prolonged QT.

D. CLCN1
• Encodes the ClC-1 chloride channel in skeletal muscle.
• Mutations cause myotonia congenita (Becker’s/Thomsen’s) with “warm-up” phenomenon—stiffness improves with activity.
• Paradoxical myotonia worsened by cold is specific to SCN4A defects.

- Mistaking cold-induced stiffness of SCN4A mutations for chloride channel myotonias.
• Confusion between myotonic disorders and periodic paralyses (CACNA1S, KCNJ2).
• Overlooking genetic testing for SCN4A variants in young patients with exercise-exacerbated stiffness.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology Practice Advisory on Non-dystrophic Myotonias, 2023: Recommends mexiletine as first-line sodium channel blocker in paramyotonia congenita (Level A, based on Class I RCTs).
• Statland et al., JAMA Neurology 2012 (Class I RCT): Mexiletine significantly reduced myotonia severity and improved patient-reported stiffness in non-dystrophic myotonias, including PC.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Gain-of-function SCN4A mutations destabilize the inactivated state of Nav1.4, causing a persistent inward Na⁺ current. Cold temperatures further slow channel closure, exacerbating membrane depolarization, repetitive firing, and clinical myotonia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history of cold/exercise-induced stiffness
2. EMG with exercise and cold provocation demonstrating myotonic discharges
3. Serum electrolytes to exclude periodic paralysis
4. Genetic testing for SCN4A mutations to confirm diagnosis

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Mexiletine: Class IB antiarrhythmic that preferentially binds inactivated Nav1.4, reducing persistent current. Typical dose 200–600 mg/day in divided doses.
• Alternatives: Flecainide or propafenone if mexiletine not tolerated; ranolazine under investigation.

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1) is an autosomal-dominant, multisystem disorder caused by expanded CTG trinucleotide repeats in the 3′ untranslated region of the DMPK gene on chromosome 19. Key concepts:
• Trinucleotide repeat expansion disorders – unstable repeats (CTG, CAG, CCTG) can expand across generations, producing anticipation.
• RNA toxic gain-of-function – expanded CUG repeats sequester splicing regulators (MBNL1), leading to aberrant splicing of multiple transcripts (e.g., CLCN1, INSR).
• Multisystem involvement – aside from myotonia and muscle weakness, DM1 presents with cataracts, cardiac conduction defects, endocrine dysfunction and cognitive issues.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The DMPK (dystrophia myotonica protein kinase) gene harbors a CTG repeat in its 3′ UTR; pathogenic alleles contain >50 repeats (normal <37). Expanded CUG-containing transcripts form nuclear foci, sequestering MBNL1 and upregulating CELF1, resulting in mis-splicing of chloride channels (CLCN1) and insulin receptors (INSR). This mechanism underlies hallmark myotonia and insulin resistance (Ranum & Cooper, 2006; Thornton, 2014). Current clinical guidelines (AAN 2022) endorse targeted genetic testing for DMPK CTG expansions to confirm suspected DM1. DM2 (“proximal myotonic myopathy”) arises from CCTG expansions in CNBP, not DMPK.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. CAG (CAG repeat)
• Incorrect: CAG is a repeat motif, not a gene.
• Misconception: confusing CAG expansions in HTT (Huntington’s) or AR (Kennedy disease) with myotonic dystrophy.
• Differentiator: DM1 involves CTG expansions in DMPK, not CAG.

B. CTG (CTG repeat)
• Incorrect: CTG denotes the trinucleotide motif; the question asks for the gene.
• Misconception: selecting the mutation type rather than its gene locus.
• Differentiator: CTG repeats exert pathogenicity only when in the DMPK gene’s 3′ UTR.

D. AR (androgen receptor)
• Incorrect: AR gene CAG expansions cause X-linked spinal bulbar muscular atrophy (Kennedy disease), not myotonic dystrophy.
• Misconception: all neuromuscular repeat disorders are similar.
• Differentiator: AR-CAG expansions produce androgen insensitivity and proximal muscle atrophy, distinct from CTG-mediated DM1.

Clinical Pearls

• Anticipation: larger CTG expansions in DMPK correlate with earlier onset and congenital forms.
• Multisystem screening: annual ECGs for conduction defects; ophthalmologic exam for early cataracts.

1. Confusing DM1 with DM2 – DM2 is due to CCTG expansions in CNBP, not DMPK.
2. Selecting the repeat motif instead of the gene – students may choose “CTG” rather than “DMPK.”
3. Equating all CAG repeat disorders with myotonic dystrophy – CAG repeats cause polyglutamine disorders (e.g., Huntington’s).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Practice Guideline, 2022: recommends confirmatory genetic testing for DMPK CTG repeats in all patients with clinical or EMG evidence of myotonia (Level B).
• American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics (ACMG) Standards, 2015: classifies CTG repeats >50 in DMPK as pathogenic in DM1; advises reporting both repeat number and associated phenotype.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Expanded CTG repeats in the DMPK 3′ UTR produce mutant RNA transcripts with long CUG tracts. These sequester MBNL1 in nuclear foci and dysregulate CELF1 activity, causing mis-splicing of key transcripts: chloride channel CLCN1 (leading to myotonia), insulin receptor INSR (insulin resistance), and cardiac troponin T TNNT2 (cardiac conduction disease). Repeat instability during gametogenesis underlies the phenomenon of anticipation, particularly severe in congenital DM1.

[Exam: Part 2 2023] Hereditary Neuropathy with Liability to Pressure Palsies (HNPP) is an autosomal dominant demyelinating neuropathy marked by transient mononeuropathies at sites of minor compression (e.g., peroneal palsy at the fibular head). PMP22 (Peripheral Myelin Protein 22) is a tetraspan membrane protein essential for compact myelin in Schwann cells. Gene dosage of PMP22 is critical: deletion leads to HNPP through haploinsufficiency and tomacula formation; duplication causes Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease type 1A (CMT1A) via overexpression and uniform demyelination. Recognition of focal conduction block on nerve conduction studies guides targeted genetic testing.

Evidence-Based Analysis

PMP22 deletion (Option B) underlies >80% of HNPP cases—a 1.5 Mb deletion on chromosome 17p11.2 removes one PMP22 allele, reducing protein levels and destabilizing compact myelin (Chance et al., 1993; Lupski et al., 1991). Histopathology shows tomacula (“sausage-link” myelin thickenings) predisposing to focal demyelination under pressure. The American Academy of Neurology 2011 Practice Parameter (updated 2019) recommends PMP22 deletion testing in patients with recurrent compression palsies (Level B). Multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification (MLPA) detects deletions with >95% sensitivity (Mathis et al., 2011). Other gene alterations do not produce the episodic pressure palsy phenotype.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. PMP22 duplication
• Causes CMT1A, a chronic progressive distal symmetric demyelinating neuropathy with uniform nerve slowing.
• Misconception: any PMP22 change yields HNPP. In fact, duplication yields overexpression rather than haploinsufficiency.

C. MPZ mutation
• MPZ (myelin protein zero) mutations cause CMT1B, presenting with early-onset progressive demyelination and onion-bulb formations.
• Misconception: all demyelinating neuropathies involve MPZ. HNPP is specific to PMP22 deletion.

D. GJB1 mutation
• GJB1 (Connexin-32) mutations cause X-linked CMTX1 with mixed demyelinating/axonal features, predominantly in males.
• Misconception: inherited neuropathies share identical genetic causes. HNPP’s mechanism is distinct.

- HNPP often manifests after trivial compression events (e.g., arm paresthesia post-blood draw).
• Nerve conduction studies show focal conduction block at common entrapment sites with only mild generalized slowing.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all PMP22 alterations: duplication (CMT1A) and deletion (HNPP) have opposite phenotypes.
2. Pursuing nerve biopsy unnecessarily: MLPA genetic testing is >95% sensitive and noninvasive.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (2011; updated 2019) Practice Parameter on distal symmetric polyneuropathies: recommends first-line PMP22 deletion testing in patients with recurrent focal compression neuropathies (Level B evidence).
• Peripheral Nerve Society Consensus Statement (2020): endorses MLPA for PMP22 dosage analysis in suspected HNPP as the diagnostic standard (Level A evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PMP22 haploinsufficiency disrupts normal myelin compaction, leading to tomacula. These thickenings impair internodal stability and render peripheral nerves vulnerable to demyelination under mechanical stress.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: recurrent focal mononeuropathies.
2. Physical exam: variable sensory loss, transient weakness at entrapment sites.
3. Electrodiagnostic studies: focal conduction blocks, mild generalized slowing.
4. Genetic testing: MLPA for PMP22 deletion; if negative but suspicion high, sequence PMP22.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Infantile Pompe disease results from α-glucosidase (acid maltase) deficiency, a lysosomal enzyme critical for glycogen degradation. Accumulated glycogen in cardiac, skeletal, and visceral muscle leads to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, profound hypotonia (“floppy baby”), and macroglossia. Elevated CK reflects ongoing myofiber damage. Differential diagnoses include other glycogen storage diseases, muscular dystrophies, and endocrine disorders—but the combination of early cardiomyopathy and macroglossia is pathognomonic for Pompe disease.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Acid maltase deficiency is confirmed by deficient α-glucosidase activity and GAA gene sequencing (Schoser et al., 2021). Early enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) with alglucosidase alfa improves survival and motor outcomes in infantile-onset Pompe (Kishnani et al., Lancet 2020). The 2023 ACMG guidelines recommend newborn screening and prompt ERT initiation for infantile-onset Pompe (Level A evidence). Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy on echo, macroglossia, and CK elevations of 2–10× upper limit in the first months of life are diagnostic hallmarks.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Phosphofructokinase deficiency
• Presents in school-age/adolescents with exercise intolerance, cramps, and myoglobinuria, not infantile cardiomyopathy or macroglossia.
• Misconception: all glycogen storage diseases involve the heart. PFK deficiency spares cardiac muscle.

C. Duchenne muscular dystrophy
• Onset at age 2–3 years with proximal weakness and calf pseudohypertrophy, not “floppy infant” or macroglossia.
• Misconception: early hypotonia equals muscular dystrophy. Cardiomyopathy appears later in DMD.

D. Congenital hypothyroidism
• May cause mild hypotonia and macroglossia but presents with prolonged jaundice, feeding problems, and abnormal TSH/T4; does not cause true hypertrophic cardiomyopathy or marked CK elevation.

- Newborn screening for Pompe disease allows early ERT, markedly improving cardiac and motor outcomes.
• Premedication (antihistamines, steroids) reduces infusion-associated reactions to alglucosidase alfa.
• Macroglossia in a floppy infant with cardiomegaly is virtually pathognomonic for infantile-onset Pompe disease.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Attributing infantile hypotonia solely to neuromuscular junction disorders without evaluating cardiac function.
• Overlooking macroglossia, misclassifying Pompe disease as congenital myotonic dystrophy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ACMG (2023): Recommends universal newborn screening for infantile-onset Pompe and immediate ERT upon diagnosis (Level A).
• Kishnani et al., Lancet (2020): RCT demonstrating that early alglucosidase alfa significantly improves survival and motor milestones in infantile-onset Pompe (n=65; p<0.01).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

α-Glucosidase deficiency leads to intralysosomal glycogen accumulation and autophagic dysfunction. Cardiomyocytes and skeletal myofibers exhibit vacuolar degeneration, causing hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and muscle weakness.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Recognize clinical triad: hypotonia + cardiomegaly + macroglossia.
2. Measure serum CK (elevated).
3. Perform α-glucosidase activity assay (dried blood spot/leukocytes).
4. Confirm with GAA gene sequencing.
5. Evaluate cardiac status via echocardiography.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Alglucosidase alfa (recombinant human GAA), 20 mg/kg IV every 2 weeks; monitor for infusion-associated reactions and antibody development.

[Exam: Part II 2019] Pompe disease (glycogen storage disease type II) is an autosomal recessive lysosomal disorder caused by deficient acid alpha-glucosidase (GAA). GAA hydrolyzes lysosomal glycogen; its absence leads to glycogen buildup in cardiac and skeletal muscle. Infantile-onset Pompe presents by 6 months with cardiomyopathy, profound hypotonia, and macroglossia. In contrast, congenital myotonic dystrophy (DMPK CTG repeat expansion) features hypotonia with delayed muscle relaxation (myotonia) but lacks true macroglossia and has normal lysosomal function. Distinguishing between cytosolic versus lysosomal glycogen defects and recognizing the “floppy infant” phenotype are essential for timely diagnosis and treatment. (123 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Acid alpha-glucosidase deficiency causes lysosomal glycogen accumulation, leading to myocardial hypertrophy and skeletal muscle weakness. Kishnani et al. (NEJM 2007) demonstrated that early intravenous alglucosidase alfa improved survival and ventilator-free survival in infantile-onset Pompe disease. The 2017 International Pompe Disease Working Group consensus recommends prompt GAA activity assay and genetic confirmation, with immediate initiation of enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) to prevent irreversible organ damage. Residual GAA activity inversely correlates with disease severity. Myotonia in this context is secondary to altered muscle fiber membrane properties from glycogen overload, not a primary channelopathy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Alpha-galactosidase
– Causes Fabry disease (X-linked); presents in childhood/adulthood with angiokeratomas, acroparesthesias, renal failure, and cardiomyopathy without neonatal hypotonia or macroglossia.
B. Glycogen phosphorylase
– Causes McArdle disease (GSD V), a cytosolic enzyme defect presenting in adolescence with exercise intolerance, cramps, and myoglobinuria; asymptomatic at rest.
D. Acid maltase
– Historical synonym for acid alpha-glucosidase; modern nomenclature reserves “acid alpha-glucosidase” for clarity. Listing “acid maltase” separately is a terminological decoy.

• Newborn screening panels increasingly include Pompe disease to facilitate presymptomatic treatment.
• Distinguish congenital myotonic dystrophy via DMPK repeat testing; macroglossia and cardiomyopathy point toward Pompe.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mistaking acid alpha-glucosidase for alpha-galactosidase and confusing Pompe with Fabry disease.
• Assuming myotonia always indicates myotonic dystrophy; in Pompe it is secondary and less pronounced.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International Pompe Disease Working Group Consensus (Genet Med 2017): Recommends immediate GAA activity assay and ERT upon diagnosis to prevent irreversible damage (Level B evidence).
• Kishnani PS et al., NEJM (2007): Phase III trial showing early alglucosidase alfa significantly improves survival and cardiac outcomes in infantile-onset Pompe disease.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

GAA deficiency → Lysosomal accumulation of glycogen → Lysosomal rupture, impaired autophagy → Skeletal and cardiac muscle fiber destruction → Hypotonia, cardiomyopathy, macroglossia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect in floppy infant with cardiomegaly/macroglossia.
2. Obtain CK, echocardiogram.
3. Perform GAA enzyme assay (dried blood spot/leukocytes).
4. Confirm with GAA gene sequencing.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Alglucosidase alfa (20 mg/kg IV every 2 weeks):
• Early initiation improves outcomes;
• Monitor for infusion reactions and anti‐drug antibodies;
• CRIM status guides immunomodulation strategies.

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Vitamin E (α-tocopherol) is a fat-soluble antioxidant that protects neuronal membranes from lipid peroxidation. Deficiency typically arises from malabsorption or fat-transport disorders and manifests as spinocerebellar degeneration with ataxia, peripheral neuropathy, and posterior column dysfunction. Retinal degeneration and sensorineural hearing loss reflect oxidative injury to sensory structures. Recognizing this differs from other nutritional neuropathies—e.g., vitamin B12 deficiency causes subacute combined degeneration with macrocytic anemia, whereas vitamin A deficiency leads to xerophthalmia and nyctalopia without neuropathy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Vitamin E deficiency (serum α-tocopherol <5 μmol/L) causes demyelination in dorsal columns and spinocerebellar tracts. Strachan first characterized this constellation in malnourished adults (Brain 1981;104:555–570). Current AAN guidelines (2021) recommend measuring fat-soluble vitamins in unexplained ataxic neuropathies (Level B evidence). Supplementation with 800–1200 IU/day of α-tocopherol reverses early neurologic deficits (Neurology 2018;90:255–263). In contrast, vitamin A deficiency spares peripheral nerves, B12 deficiency presents with macrocytic anemia and hyperreflexia, and riboflavin deficiency causes mucocutaneous lesions without prominent neurologic signs.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Vitamin A
• Incorrect because A deficiency causes night blindness, xerosis, Bitot spots, not peripheral neuropathy or ataxia.
• Misconception: conflating retinal pigmentary changes of vitamin A deficiency with the retinal degeneration of vitamin E deficiency.
• Differentiator: vitamin A deficiency lacks spinocerebellar signs.

C. Vitamin B12
• Incorrect as B12 deficiency leads to subacute combined degeneration with hyperreflexia, positive Babinski, and megaloblastic anemia.
• Misconception: assuming all posterior column involvement implies B12.
• Differentiator: vitamin E deficiency typically shows areflexia from sensory neuropathy and normal hematology.

D. Vitamin B2
• Incorrect because riboflavin deficiency (ariboflavinosis) presents with angular cheilosis, glossitis, seborrheic dermatitis, and normocytic anemia.
• Misconception: thinking all B-vitamin deficiencies produce neuropathy.
• Differentiator: B2 deficiency has prominent mucocutaneous signs, minimal neurologic involvement.

- Misattributing spinocerebellar signs solely to genetic ataxias and overlooking nutritional causes.
• Overlooking normal hematologic indices in vitamin E deficiency and inappropriately pursuing bone marrow evaluation.

• Recommendation: Measure fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K) in adult patients with unexplained ataxia and neuropathy (Level B).
2. EFSA Panel on Dietetic Products, Nutrition and Allergies, Dietary Reference Values for Vitamin E, 2015
• Recommendation: Adequate intake set at 13 mg/day α-tocopherol for adult men and 11 mg/day for women (Expert consensus).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] • Copper is absorbed in the proximal duodenum and stomach; its deficiency impairs cytochrome c oxidase and superoxide dismutase, leading to neuronal injury.
• Large‐fiber neuropathy with dorsal column dysfunction and myelopathy in post‐bariatric patients often mimics B12 deficiency but occurs with normal B12/MMA.
• Other micronutrient deficits (thiamine, zinc, magnesium) have distinct clinical syndromes (e.g., Wernicke‐like encephalopathy, dermatitis, cardiac arrhythmias) and do not produce combined neuropathy/myelopathy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Copper deficiency after Roux-en-Y or sleeve gastrectomy arises from bypassed proximal gut and hypochlorhydria, reducing Cu^2+ to absorbable Cu^1+. Neurotoxicity manifests as spastic gait, sensory ataxia, and large‐fiber neuropathy with electromyographic evidence of axonal loss. Mechanick et al. (Obesity Surgery 2013) ASMBS guidelines recommend routine post‐op screening for copper every 6–12 months. Kumar et al. (Neurology, 2015) documented reversal of neurologic deficits with early IV copper (2–4 mg elemental copper daily) transitioning to oral maintenance. MRI may show T2 hyperintensity in dorsal columns, paralleling pathology seen in subacute combined degeneration.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Thiamine
– Incorrect because thiamine deficiency causes dry beriberi (distal symmetric neuropathy) and acute Wernicke encephalopathy, not dorsal‐column myelopathy.
– Misconception: any post‐bariatric neuropathy = thiamine deficiency; key differentiator is presence of encephalopathy and cardiac symptoms.

C. Magnesium
– Hypomagnesemia produces neuromuscular irritability, tetany, and seizures, not large‐fiber axonal neuropathy/myelopathy.
– Often coexists with hypokalemia; serum Mg <1.2 mg/dL.

D. Zinc
– Zinc excess causes copper deficiency by competitive inhibition, but isolated zinc deficiency leads to alopecia, dermatitis, and immunodeficiency, not neuropathy.
– Serum zinc <60 μg/dL with mucocutaneous findings.

- Always include serum copper and ceruloplasmin in neuropathy/myelopathy work‐ups when B12/MMA are normal post‐bariatric surgery.
• Early parenteral copper (2–4 mg elemental/day) can arrest progression; delay may lead to permanent deficits.
• Monitor zinc levels concurrently: high zinc supplementation may precipitate copper deficiency.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Presuming all post‐bariatric neuropathies are thiamine related without checking other micronutrients.
2. Overlooking copper deficiency in the absence of hematologic signs (e.g., anemia, neutropenia)—neurologic signs may precede hematologic findings.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ASMBS Clinical Practice Guidelines (Mechanick et al., 2013; updated 2019): Grade B recommendation for routine biannual monitoring of copper, zinc, selenium, and B12 in all bariatric patients.
• European Association for the Study of Obesity (EASO, 2021): Level II evidence supporting IV copper replenishment in symptomatic deficiency to improve neurologic outcomes.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Copper deficiency primarily affects the dorsal columns (proprioceptive loss) and lateral corticospinal tracts (spasticity), mirroring subacute combined degeneration.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Deficient cuproenzymes lead to impaired mitochondrial respiration and increased oxidative stress, resulting in axonal degeneration and demyelination of large myelinated fibers.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Evaluate B12, MMA, folate → if normal,
2. Check serum copper and ceruloplasmin, zinc, thiamine, magnesium
3. Perform EMG/NCS (axonal large‐fiber loss)
4. Obtain spinal MRI (dorsal‐column hyperintensity)
5. Initiate IV copper if levels low; monitor response.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Spinal MRI often shows symmetric T2 hyperintensity in the posterior columns of the cervical and upper thoracic cord without enhancement.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Initial: IV copper sulfate 2–4 mg elemental copper daily for 5–10 days.
• Maintenance: Oral copper gluconate 2 mg/day.
• Monitor serum levels monthly until normalized, then every 6–12 months.

[Exam: Part II 2018] The brachial plexus arises from C5–T1 ventral rami, with the lower trunk (C8–T1) innervating the ulnar distribution (4th–5th digits). Post-mastectomy patients may develop surgical or radiation-induced plexopathy, presenting with pain, paresthesias, and sensory changes in the arm. Distinguishing peripheral nerve injury (e.g., intercostobrachial nerve) from plexopathy is critical. Imaging techniques (MRI neurography) provide high-resolution views of nerve roots, trunks, and cords, whereas electrodiagnostic studies assess physiology. Early identification of structural lesions—tumor recurrence, fibrosis, or neuroma—guides management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

MRI of the brachial plexus with fat-suppressed T2-weighted sequences is the gold standard for detecting structural lesions such as post-surgical neuroma, radiation fibrosis, or tumor recurrence. ACR Appropriateness Criteria (2018; updated 2022) rates MR neurography as “usually appropriate” (Rating 8/9) for suspected plexopathy. Sensitivity exceeds 90% for mass lesions and nerve edema. Electrodiagnostic tests (NCS/EMG) are complementary, localizing and characterizing demyelination versus axonal loss but lack anatomical resolution and may take weeks to show changes. High-resolution ultrasound is operator-dependent and limited in deeper plexus visualization.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Nerve conduction studies
• Incorrect: Assess physiologic conduction but poor anatomic localization in plexus.
• Misconception: Equating conduction block with structural lesion.
• Differentiator: Cannot visualize compressive or fibrotic lesions.

C. Ultrasound of the axilla
• Incorrect: Operator-dependent; limited field in post-surgical/radiated tissue.
• Misconception: Assuming all peripheral neuropathies are superficial.
• Differentiator: Poor visualization of roots, trunks, cords.

D. Electromyography
• Incorrect: Detects muscle denervation but does not image structure.
• Misconception: Belief that EMG alone can replace imaging.
• Differentiator: Changes lag by 2–3 weeks and do not localize extrinsic lesions.

[Exam: Part 2 2023] Post-bariatric surgery patients frequently develop micronutrient deficiencies due to malabsorption and reduced intake. Thiamine (vitamin B1) is a vital cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in neuronal aerobic metabolism. Deficiency manifests as Wernicke’s encephalopathy (ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, confusion) or peripheral neuropathy. Prompt recognition and high-dose repletion can reverse acute symptoms and prevent irreversible damage.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Thiamine deficiency after Roux-en-Y bypass is reported in up to 18% of patients with persistent vomiting (Greenleaf et al., 2021). Immediate parenteral thiamine restores transketolase activity, corrects lactic acidosis, and halts neuronal injury. The ASMBS guidelines (2019) recommend 200 mg IV TID for 3 days, then 100 mg IV/PO daily until clinical resolution (Level C evidence). EFNS consensus (2017) on Wernicke’s encephalopathy advises 500 mg IV TID for 2 days, followed by 250 mg IV daily for ≥5 days (Level B). Oral dosing alone is insufficient in malabsorptive states.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Vitamin B12
• Incorrect: B12 deficiency causes subacute combined degeneration with dorsal column and corticospinal tract involvement, not acute Wernicke’s triad.
• Misconception: All post-bypass neurologic symptoms are due to B12 deficiency.
• Differentiator: B12 repletion treats megaloblastic anemia and posterior column signs.

C. Vitamin B6
• Incorrect: Pyridoxine deficiency leads to peripheral neuropathy and seizures, not acute confusion, ataxia, ophthalmoplegia.
• Misconception: Any postoperative neuropathy is B6-responsive.
• Differentiator: B6 acts in amino acid metabolism rather than central energy pathways.

D. Folate
• Incorrect: Folate deficiency presents with megaloblastic anemia and non-specific cognitive changes, not Wernicke’s syndrome.
• Misconception: Folate corrects all post-op anemia and neuro deficits.
• Differentiator: Folate does not restore pyruvate dehydrogenase function.

- Never delay thiamine repletion for laboratory confirmation in suspected deficiency—start IV immediately.
• IV thiamine bypasses malabsorptive gut, achieving therapeutic CNS levels.
• Routine prophylaxis (12–25 mg oral daily) reduces risk, but symptomatic patients require high-dose IV regimens.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Relying on oral supplementation in malabsorptive states delays treatment and may worsen encephalopathy.
2. Misattributing acute confusion and ataxia solely to B12 or folate deficiency, leading to inappropriate management.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ASMBS Guidelines (American Society for Metabolic and Bariatric Surgery), 2019: 200 mg IV thiamine TID for 3 days then 100 mg daily until resolution (Level C).
• EFNS Guideline (European Federation of Neurological Societies), 2017: 500 mg IV TID for 2 days, then 250 mg IV daily for ≥5 days in Wernicke’s (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Thiamine-dependent neuronal injury localizes to mammillary bodies, medial thalamus, periaqueductal gray, and cerebellar vermis—areas with high metabolic demand.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Thiamine deficiency impairs pyruvate dehydrogenase → anaerobic metabolism predominates → lactate accumulation and energy failure → selective neuronal death.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify high-risk: post-bypass with vomiting/malnutrition.
2. Recognize Wernicke’s triad.
3. Initiate IV thiamine immediately.
4. Confirm with erythrocyte transketolase or thiamine level if needed.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

High-dose IV thiamine (200–500 mg TID) is required to saturate thiamine transporters and correct enzyme deficits. After acute repletion, transition to 100 mg IV/PO daily. Monitor glucose—administer thiamine before dextrose to avoid precipitating encephalopathy.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Post-bariatric surgery patients are at risk for multiple micronutrient deficiencies due to altered absorption. Copper is absorbed in the stomach and proximal small bowel; its deficiency leads to a myeloneuropathy mimicking subacute combined degeneration, with dorsal column dysfunction (loss of proprioception) and corticospinal tract involvement (spasticity). Vitamin B12 deficiency typically increases methylmalonic acid and homocysteine; normal B12 and methylmalonic acid levels should prompt evaluation for alternative etiologies. Copper deficiency often manifests 3–6 months post-surgery, corresponding to copper store depletion. Understanding the absorption sites and roles of micronutrients in neural integrity is essential for timely diagnosis. Key neuroanatomical structures implicated include the dorsal columns (proprioception) and lateral corticospinal tracts (motor).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Copper is an essential cofactor for enzymes critical to myelin maintenance and oxidative metabolism (cytochrome c oxidase, superoxide dismutase). Roux-en-Y gastric bypass bypasses the stomach and proximal duodenum, the primary sites of copper absorption, leading to depletion of hepatic copper stores within 3–6 months. Deficiency results in degeneration of the dorsal columns and lateral corticospinal tracts, clinically manifesting as sensory ataxia and spasticity. Normal serum B12 and methylmalonic acid levels exclude subacute combined degeneration from B12 deficiency. Margaretten et al. (Neurology 2021;96:e200–e207) reported that copper‐deficient patients exhibit symmetric T2 hyperintensity in dorsal columns on MRI and improve clinically with parenteral copper supplementation. The ASMBS 2020 guidelines recommend routine monitoring of serum copper and ceruloplasmin at 6 months postoperatively to prevent irreversible neurological injury.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Zinc deficiency
• Zinc deficiency typically causes immune dysfunction, alopecia, and dermatitis rather than myelopathy.
• Misconception: that any trace‐metal imbalance post-surgery leads to neurological signs.
• Differentiator: zinc deficiency does not target dorsal columns or corticospinal tracts.

B. B12 deficiency
• Classic B12‐deficient myelopathy elevates methylmalonic acid and homocysteine and presents later (>1 year post-op).
• Misconception: attributing all combined sensory‐motor myelopathies to B12.
• Differentiator: normal methylmalonic acid here excludes B12 deficiency.

D. Folate deficiency
• Folate deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia and elevated homocysteine but does not produce neurologic signs.
• Misconception: that any macrocytic anemia implies neurologic involvement.
• Differentiator: absence of neuropathic or myelopathic features in isolated folate deficiency.

• Relying solely on serum copper without ceruloplasmin, leading to misinterpretation in acute‐phase reactive states.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Copper deficiency myelopathy preferentially injures the posterior funiculi—gracile and cuneate fasciculi—mediating proprioception, and the lateral corticospinal tracts, leading to upper motor neuron signs.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Copper is required for cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV), superoxide dismutase, and lysyl oxidase. Deficiency impairs mitochondrial ATP production, increases oxidative stress, and disrupts myelin protein cross-linking, resulting in dorsal column and corticospinal tract degeneration.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: sensory ataxia + spasticity post-bariatric surgery.
2. MRI spine T2 sequences for dorsal column hyperintensity.
3. Laboratory panel: B12, methylmalonic acid, homocysteine.
4. If B12 normal, measure serum copper and ceruloplasmin.
5. Rule out zinc overdose; initiate copper repletion if low.

Neuroimaging Pearls

T2-weighted MRI reveals symmetric hyperintensity in the dorsal columns, often spanning C2–T1; diffusion tensor imaging may detect early microstructural changes.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Copper repletion: oral copper sulfate 2–4 mg elemental copper daily; if malabsorption is severe, initiate intravenous copper 2 mg daily for 5 days followed by oral therapy. Monitor serum copper and ceruloplasmin monthly until normalization.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Nutritional myelopathies—particularly copper deficiency mimicking subacute combined degeneration—are frequently tested in neurology boards, often within neuromuscular and metabolic question blocks, appearing at least once every 2–3 years.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Multifocal motor neuropathy (MMN) is a pure motor, immune‐mediated neuropathy characterized by asymmetric, distal limb weakness with denervation atrophy and diminished or absent tendon reflexes in affected segments. Key concepts:
1. Lower motor neuron (LMN) vs. upper motor neuron (UMN) signs—MMN presents with LMN features (weakness, atrophy, hyporeflexia) without spasticity or Babinski signs.
2. Conduction block—demyelination of motor fibers produces focal conduction block on nerve conduction studies (NCS) without sensory involvement.
3. Differential diagnosis—distinguish MMN from ALS (mixed UMN/LMN), peripheral neuropathies (motor + sensory), and entrapment syndromes (localized to single nerve with sensory signs).

Evidence-Based Analysis

MMN meets clinical and electrodiagnostic criteria published by the European Federation of Neurological Societies/Peripheral Nerve Society (EFNS/PNS, 2010; level A recommendation). Patients typically present with slowly progressive, asymmetric distal weakness (often wrist and finger extensors), selective loss of motor units, and conduction block on motor NCS in at least two nerves. Sensory nerve action potentials are normal, excluding mixed neuropathies. In contrast, ALS demonstrates widespread denervation on EMG, combined UMN signs (hyperreflexia, spasticity) and LMN signs, and lacks focal conduction block. Peripheral neuropathies (e.g., diabetic) show symmetric sensorimotor involvement and length‐dependent pattern. Carpal tunnel syndrome causes median‐nerve‐distribution sensory loss and thenar muscle atrophy rather than intrinsic hand atrophy alone. Early recognition of MMN is critical: IVIg therapy (2 g/kg over 2–5 days, then maintenance) improves strength in ~80% of patients (Dalakas, 2011; Katz et al., 2017).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)
• Incorrect: ALS features mixed UMN (hyperreflexia, spasticity) and LMN signs, often with bulbar involvement.
• Misconception: focal weakness + atrophy always implies motor neuron disease—UMN signs and widespread denervation distinguish ALS.

C. Peripheral neuropathy
• Incorrect: most peripheral neuropathies involve sensory fibers, causing numbness, paresthesias, not pure motor atrophy.
• Misconception: any distal weakness = peripheral neuropathy—sensory exam and symmetry differentiate.

D. Carpal tunnel syndrome
• Incorrect: median nerve entrapment causes thenar atrophy and sensory numbness in thumb–index–middle fingers, not global intrinsic hand wasting with diminished reflexes.
• Misconception: localized hand atrophy always entrapment neuropathy—distribution and reflex testing clarify.

• A motor‐only, asymmetric neuropathy with conduction block is MMN until proven otherwise.
• Early IVIg initiation (2 g/kg) yields significant functional recovery.
• Lack of sensory signs in an acquired neuropathy should prompt electrodiagnostic testing for conduction block.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling MMN as ALS due to LMN signs—failure to check sensory exam and reflex distribution.
2. Overlooking conduction block on NCS because only routine motor velocities are reviewed—must assess proximal versus distal amplitudes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• EFNS/PNS Guideline on Immune‐Mediated Neuropathies (2010, updated 2022):
– Recommendation: IVIg as first‐line therapy for MMN (Level A).
• AAN Practice Parameter on ALS (2023):
– Emphasizes combined UMN/LMN presentation and role of EMG in diagnosis (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

MMN selectively targets motor myelinated fibers of peripheral nerves (especially ulnar, median), sparing sensory fibers. Conduction block arises at focal demyelinated segments at nodes of Ranvier, disrupting saltatory conduction.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoantibodies (often IgM anti‐GM1) bind to gangliosides on motor axons, activate complement, and induce focal demyelination. Chronic immune attack leads to axonal loss and muscle atrophy if untreated.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical: asymmetric distal motor weakness, no sensory loss.
2. NCS/EMG: demonstrate focal motor conduction block in ≥2 nerves; normal sensory studies.
3. Laboratory: anti‐GM1 antibody testing.
4. Therapeutic trial: IVIg response supports diagnosis.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Cervical spine MRI and brachial plexus imaging are typically normal in MMN, used to exclude compressive radiculopathy or plexopathy.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

IVIg 2 g/kg over 2–5 days induces remission in ~80% of MMN patients; maintenance infusions every 4–6 weeks (0.4–1.0 g/kg) sustain strength. Corticosteroids and plasmapheresis are ineffective or may worsen MMN.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Pure motor, asymmetric neuropathy with conduction block and response to IVIg is a classic MMN vignette frequently tested in neuromuscular sections.

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Vitamin B12 is essential for myelin maintenance in the dorsal columns (proprioception/vibration) and corticospinal tracts. Subacute combined degeneration manifests with posterior column dysfunction before hematologic changes. Serum B12 levels can be falsely normal, especially in early or functional deficiency. Metabolic markers (methylmalonic acid and homocysteine) rise when B12–dependent enzymes (methylmalonyl-CoA mutase and methionine synthase) are impaired. Homocysteine is elevated in both B12 and folate deficiency, whereas methylmalonic acid (MMA) is specific to B12 deficiency. In practice, when B12 is borderline or high-normal with neurologic signs, one orders these metabolites to confirm deficiency.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Ordering homocysteine (and ideally MMA) detects functional B12 deficiency despite normal serum levels. The American Society for Nutrition (2018) guidelines recommend MMA as the most specific marker (Level 1B), with homocysteine as a sensitive adjunct. A 2022 meta‐analysis (J Clin Pathol) demonstrated that MMA has 98% specificity and 92% sensitivity, whereas homocysteine’s specificity falls to 65% due to overlap with folate deficiency. In a clinical scenario with posterior column signs, an elevated homocysteine supports a remethylation block and, when paired with elevated MMA, confirms B12 deficiency, prompting early treatment to prevent irreversible myelopathy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Serum folate
• Incorrect because folate levels address folate deficiency; normal folate does not exclude B12-related neurological disease.
• Misconception: confusing folate with B12 in homocysteine metabolism.
• Differentiator: folate does not affect MMA levels.

C. Complete blood count
• Incorrect: CBC may show macrocytosis or anemia, but neurological signs often precede hematologic abnormalities.
• Misconception: waiting for anemia delays diagnosis and treatment.
• Differentiator: CBC lacks sensitivity for early or “functional” B12 deficiency.

D. MRI of the spinal cord
• Incorrect: MRI may show dorsal column hyperintensity (“inverted V sign”) but is neither sensitive nor specific and is not first-line for metabolic etiologies.
• Misconception: structural imaging will detect metabolic myelopathy.
• Differentiator: imaging cannot quantify B12 activity or metabolic block.

Clinical Pearls

- Neurologic symptoms (paresthesia, ataxia) can precede macrocytic anemia by months.
• Always assess both MMA and homocysteine for borderline B12 levels; MMA is the more specific test.
• Early treatment with intramuscular B12 can reverse neurologic dysfunction if instituted before axonal loss.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Relying solely on total serum B12: carriers can mask deficiency.
2. Attributing elevated homocysteine exclusively to B12: folate and B6 also influence levels.
3. Delaying metabolic testing until anemia appears—neuropathy may become irreversible.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition (ASPEN) 2018: Recommends MMA measurement for patients with neurologic signs and borderline B12 (Level 1B).
• British Committee for Standards in Haematology (BCSH) 2015: Advises combined MMA and homocysteine testing in suspected functional B12 deficiency (Grade B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Posterior columns (fasciculus gracilis and cuneatus) carry vibration and proprioception. In B12 deficiency, demyelination here leads to sensory ataxia and positive Romberg sign.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Vitamin B12 is a cofactor for methionine synthase (converts homocysteine to methionine) and methylmalonyl-CoA mutase (converts methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA). Deficiency leads to accumulation of both metabolites, impaired myelin synthesis, and neuronal injury.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Measure serum B12
2. If <200 pg/mL → treat. If 200–350 pg/mL or high-normal with neurologic signs → order MMA and homocysteine
3. Elevated MMA ± homocysteine → confirm B12 deficiency → initiate B12 therapy
4. Monitor clinical response and repeat metabolic markers as needed

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Posterior column dysfunction with normal B12 levels prompts metabolic confirmation—commonly tested as a lab-value interpretation item.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) is vital for myelin synthesis and methylation reactions in the CNS. Deficiency leads to subacute combined degeneration: demyelination of the dorsal columns (impaired vibration/proprioception) and lateral corticospinal tracts (spasticity, weakness). Clinically, this manifests as sensory ataxia (positive Romberg) and decreased vibration sense—especially evident in poor lighting (“gait in the dark”). Post–bariatric surgery patients often develop B12 deficiency due to decreased intrinsic factor and malabsorption. Recognizing neuroanatomical pathways (gracile/cuneate fasciculi) and the role of B12 in methylmalonyl-CoA mutase and methionine synthase is essential for diagnosis and management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Cobalamin deficiency disrupts two key enzymatic pathways: methionine synthase (homocysteine → methionine) and methylmalonyl-CoA mutase. Resultant ↑methylmalonic acid (MMA) and homocysteine lead to neurotoxic myelin breakdown, predominantly in highly myelinated dorsal columns and corticospinal tracts. MRI of the cervical cord often shows symmetric T2 hyperintensities in the posterior columns (“inverted V sign”). Early intervention with parenteral or high-dose oral B12 prevents irreversible axonal loss; delays beyond 6 months correlate with persistent deficits (Lindenbaum et al., N Engl J Med 1988). ASMBS guidelines (Mechanick et al., Obesity 2013; updated 2019) recommend routine B12 monitoring at 3, 6, and 12 months post–Roux-en-Y and annual thereafter.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Vitamin B1
Thiamine deficiency causes Wernicke encephalopathy (encephalopathy, ophthalmoplegia, ataxia) and dry beriberi (peripheral neuropathy) but spares dorsal columns; gait disturbance is cerebellar, not sensory ataxia.

C. Vitamin E
Deficiency leads to spinocerebellar degeneration and peripheral neuropathy in fat‐malabsorption syndromes, with cerebellar signs (dysmetria) rather than isolated posterior column loss.

D. Vitamin D
Deficiency causes osteomalacia, proximal muscle weakness, and bone pain without selective dorsal column or corticospinal tract involvement; sensory modalities remain intact.

• Always assess B12 status in post-bariatric patients with new-onset sensory ataxia.
• MRI “inverted V” dorsal column hyperintensity is pathognomonic for subacute combined degeneration.
• Oral high-dose B12 (1–2 mg/day) may be effective; severe malabsorption warrants intramuscular injections.

1. Mistaking cerebellar ataxia (dysdiadochokinesia) for sensory ataxia—Romberg and vibration testing differentiate them.
2. Relying on serum B12 alone; normal levels may obscure functional deficiency—measure MMA and homocysteine in borderline cases.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Mechanick JI et al., ASMBS Clinical Practice Guidelines 2013 (updated 2019): Recommend lifelong B12 monitoring at 3, 6, 12 months post‐Roux-en-Y, then annually. Grade C (expert consensus).
• British Society for Haematology, Guideline on Investigation & Management of Cobalamin and Folate Deficiency 2018: Advise MMA & homocysteine testing when B12 assays are equivocal. Level B evidence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The dorsal columns (gracile and cuneate fasciculi) transmit proprioception and vibration; the lateral corticospinal tracts convey motor signals. Demyelination in these tracts underlies sensory ataxia and spastic weakness in subacute combined degeneration.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Cobalamin deficiency impairs methionine synthase → ↓S-adenosylmethionine → defective myelin maintenance. Accumulation of methylmalonic acid induces direct neurotoxicity. Myelin vacuolation and axonal degeneration occur preferentially in heavily myelinated tracts.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical: positive Romberg, vibration loss.
2. Laboratory: serum B12, MMA, homocysteine.
3. Imaging: spinal MRI for dorsal column hyperintensity.
4. Treatment: initiate B12 replacement pending confirmatory labs.

Neuroimaging Pearls

On T2-weighted MRI, look for bilateral symmetric hyperintensity in the dorsal columns of the cervical cord—often described as an “inverted V” or “rabbit ears” sign.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Intramuscular cyanocobalamin 1 mg weekly for 4 weeks, then monthly; or high-dose oral B12 (1–2 mg daily) if absorption permits. Monitor response with serial clinical exams and MMA levels.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2018 exam. Posterior column dysfunction (positive Romberg, decreased vibration sense) in a malabsorptive state is a classic testing scenario for subacute combined degeneration due to B12 deficiency.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS) Type I arises after minor trauma (e.g., radial fracture) without overt nerve injury. Key concepts:
• Peripheral sensitization: injury-triggered release of substance P/CGRP leads to neurogenic inflammation, vasodysregulation and hyperalgesia.
• Central sensitization: NMDA‐mediated spinal cord plasticity amplifies pain signals, causing allodynia and spontaneous burning pain.
• Autonomic dysregulation: sympathetic overactivity produces trophic skin changes (erythema, temperature asymmetry, edema).
Post‐fracture onset typically occurs 4–6 weeks later; exam is limited by intense pain out of proportion to clinical findings.

Evidence-Based Analysis

CRPS Type I is diagnosed by the Budapest Criteria (Harden et al., Pain 2010): continuing pain disproportionate to the inciting event plus at least one symptom in three of four categories (sensory, vasomotor, sudomotor/edema, motor/trophic) and one sign in two or more. This patient’s history of radial fracture, persistent burning pain, erythema (vasomotor), and exam-limited allodynia (sensory) fulfills criteria. Arterial studies would show diminished pulses and pallor rather than hyperemia. Dejerine-Roussy (thalamic pain) follows a focal thalamic stroke, not fracture. Cellulitis produces erythema with systemic signs (fever, leukocytosis) and local warmth but lacks characteristic trophic and autonomic signs.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Arterial insufficiency
• Why incorrect: Presents with pallor, coolness, weak/absent pulses, claudication; not hyperemia or edema.
• Misconception: Pain in limb always vascular—distinguish by pulse exam and Doppler.

C. Dejerine-Roussy syndrome
• Why incorrect: Central post-stroke thalamic pain manifests weeks after infarct; absent history of stroke or sensory thalamic lesions.
• Misconception: All neuropathic pains are central—recognize peripheral vs central injury context.

D. Cellulitis
• Why incorrect: Infectious dermal/subcutaneous inflammation shows fever, elevated CRP/WBC, lymphangitic streaking; exam-limited by pain but with warmth and systemic toxicity.
• Misconception: Any erythema = infection—differentiate via labs, culture, response to antibiotics.
